Charizard.overview: Charizard's overall solid stats, great typing, and splendid movepool allow it to perform multiple roles effectively, such as special wallbreaker and physical sweeper. Its typing and decent bulk also give it a fair amount of defensive utility, allowing it to check threats like Ribombee. However, Charizard struggles to get past many metagame staples like Gigalith, while its Speed tier leaves it unable to check multiple threats like Sneasel and Dragon Dance Scrafty.

sets.name: Special Attacker
sets.description: Charizard makes for a great wallbreaker and offensive check to Pokemon like Ribombee, Tsareena, and Gallade. Defog allows Charizard to clear all entry hazards and is the preferred option due to Charizard's ability to force out common entry hazard setters like Palossand and Weezing. Toxic cripples switch-ins such as Lanturn and Gigalith; it also allows Charizard to pressure Jellicent and Aromatisse more effectively. Lastly, Focus Blast immediately pressures Rock-types like Regirock. Fighting-types like Passimian and Bulk Up Scrafty appreciate Charizard pressuring their switch-ins such as Ribombee. In exchange, they can take on Charizard's answers like Gigalith and Lanturn. Pokemon like Sandaconda and Jellicent make for good partners thanks to their ability to take on attackers that force Charizard out like Lycanroc and Basculin, respectively. On sun teams, Solar Power is an option, as it makes Charizard significantly harder to switch into. On such teams, it should forego Hurricane for Solar Beam and run Weather Ball in the fourth moveslot, and Choice Specs is an option over Heavy-Duty Boots. Charizard should also be paired with other Pokemon that take advantage of sun such as Shiftry.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Charizard's impressive Speed and coverage allows it to outspeed common Choice Scarf users like Togedemaru and Passimian as well as threaten its would-be switchins such as Gigalith after a Dragon Dance. Roost allows Charizard to switch into threats like Ribombee and Whimsicott as well as set up more easily, while Thunder Punch is Charizard's best option to hit Jellicent, having a solid chance of 2HKOing it; it also hits Archeops and opposing Charizard. Charizard's middling Attack means it can't sweep unless the opposing team is very weakened; this makes wallbreakers like Vikavolt and Trevenant very appreciated. They can both take on defensive behemoths such as Jellicent and Regirock that Charizard struggles against. Mach Punch Hitmontop can check Lycanroc; similarly, Froslass can wear down its shared checks with Charizard, like Gigalith, particularly with Spikes.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Raichu's vast movepool, high Speed, ability, and respectable Special Attack allow it to force out many threats like Lapras, Pincurchin, and Choice-locked Manectric, giving it multiple setup opportunities. It can also use more passive Pokemon such as Mareanie as setup fodder. Focus Blast lets Raichu break through special walls like Type: Null and Munchlax and targets Silvally-Grass and Vibrava, which take little damage from its other moves. Surf is usually preferred to Grass Knot, as it hits Stunfisk harder than any other move, but Grass Knot eases the matchup against Palpitoad. Lightning Rod is Raichu's best ability, as it lets Raichu provide its team with an Electric-type immunity and take advantage of Choice-locked Manectric and Silvally-Electric to gain setup opportunities. Volt Switch can be used to give Raichu a more prominent role early-game, Protect can be used to prevent priority users like Falinks and Fraxure from revenge killing it, and Knock Off can be used to cripple Eviolite users like Type: Null and Vibrava and make them easier to revenge kill, but it struggles to fit any of these moves over important coverage.

Raichu fits well on entry hazard-stacking teams, as the chip damage lets it break through targets like Throh and different Silvally formes more easily. Roselia can handle Grass-types that Raichu struggles against such as Gourgeist-XL and Shiinotic, and other hazard setters such as Mareanie, Palpitoad, and Hippopotas can effectively answer priority users like Falinks. Due to its poor bulk, Raichu appreciates partners that can bring it in safely. Silvally-Bug and Silvally-Psychic are both notable for handling Grass- and Fighting-types like Roselia, Gourgeist-XL, and Throh and can potentially bring Raichu in safely with U-turn or Parting Shot against targets like Mareanie and Musharna. Type: Null is also notable, as it can switch into and cripple Grass-types like Gourgeist-XL easily. Due to its tendency to get worn down quickly, Raichu highly appreciates entry hazard removal from Mr. Rime, Galarian Mr. Mime, and Hitmontop; the former two can check Roselia and Gloom and provide Raichu with another chance at sweeping with Healing Wish, and the latter can pressure physical attackers like Falinks and Persian and work with Raichu to overwhelm Gourgeist-XL. All of them appreciate Raichu pressuring Ghost-types like Dusclops, and Hitmontop also appreciates Raichu handling Mareanie and Flying-types like Vespiquen and Togetic.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Raichu stands out from Manectric as a Choice-locked Electric-type thanks to its expansive coverage options, which allow it to hit Ground-types like Stunfisk and Palpitoad that would otherwise easily block its Volt Switch, thus giving it the upper hand in generating momentum. Its excellent Speed also makes it one of the naturally fastest Pokemon in the metagame, letting it check targets like Basculin, Silvally-Rock, and non-Choice Scarf Manectric. Choice Specs-boosted Thunderbolt makes Raichu very difficult to switch into, with even Electric-resistant Pokemon like Gourgeist and Leafeon struggling to take two hits when entry hazards are up. Focus Blast lets Raichu offensively check Type: Null and Dubwool and is its best option for hitting Seaking and Vibrava, which otherwise easily block its Volt Switch. Surf notably prevents Raichu from getting blocked by Stunfisk and deals more damage than Grass Knot to Hippopotas. Alternatively, Grass Knot eases the matchup against Palpitoad, but it leaves Raichu unable to deal with Stunfisk. Lightning Rod lets Raichu take advantage of Silvally-Electric and Choice-locked Manectric, potentially boosting its Special Attack and making it even more difficult to switch into. Raichu can also run a similar set with Choice Scarf; however, the drop in power is fairly noticeable, and it is generally outclassed by other Choice Scarf users such as Manectric and Mr. Mime that can provide additional utility with Switcheroo and Trick, respectively.

Roselia stands out as a great partner; not only can it provide entry hazards such as Spikes and Toxic Spikes, which can help Raichu break through foes like Gourgeist and Type: Null more easily, but it also takes advantage of Raichu bringing in foes like Shiinotic and Gourgeist-XL, which it can pressure offensively or use as setup fodder, respectively. It also greatly appreciates Raichu dealing with Vespiquen and Mareanie, which can easily remove its hazards, as well as Steel-types like Mawile and Klang. Galarian Mr. Mime appreciates Raichu bringing it in safely with Volt Switch, and it can pressure foes that Raichu struggles to break through such as Roselia and Gloom, as well as give it a better chance at cleaning late-game with Healing Wish. Fire-types like Heatmor and Raboot similarly benefit from Volt Switch and can pressure targets that Raichu invites in like Shiinotic and Silvally-Grass; the former can even take advantage of Manectric trying to check Choice-locked Raichu with Fire-type coverage. In return, Raichu pressures Water-types like Mareanie and Lapras. Palpitoad and Throh can provide a solid defensive backbone, being able to switch into potential revenge killers such as Falinks, Choice Band Fraxure, and Pikachu; the former can also easily switch into Manectric, which can otherwise take advantage of Raichu if it's Choice locked, and the latter also fits well on entry hazard-stacking teams, as it can use Circle Throw to further wear down the opposing team and make it easier for Raichu to perform its job. Silvally-Bug forms an effective VoltTurn core with Raichu, as they effectively deal with each other's checks.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Persian's uncontested Speed tier, Technician Fake Out, and solid coverage make it a decent, although weak, revenge killer. However, it suffers extreme competition in this role from Pikachu, which boasts Extreme Speed and a greater offensive presence at the expense of some Speed. Fake Out lets Persian get extra damage on the foe without punishment and stall for extra poison damage, letting it follow up with Double-Edge in order to secure KOs on targets like the Silvally formes. Fake Out can also be used to pick off heavily weakened targets that have boosted their Speed, like Fraxure, in a pinch. Knock Off removes items from bulky switch-ins that otherwise disregard anything Persian can do to them, such as Mawile, Dusclops, and Hippopotas, and provides coverage for Ghost-types like Drakloak. U-turn lets Persian keep up momentum for its team, saving it from floundering against bulky foes like Stonjourner, Mawile, and Dusclops. Hypnosis can be used over Knock Off to better cripple switch-ins like Mawile but is unreliable due to its poor accuracy and leaves Persian unable to damage Ghost-types outside of U-turn. Silk Scarf is preferred in order to boost Persian's most important attacks without further cutting into its already limited longevity. Technician is vital in order to let Fake Out deal significant damage.

Persian is a good fit for bulky offense teams utilizing Spikes, which help it gradually overwhelm its switch-ins with Spikes damage, Fake Out, and U-turn. Offensive Roselia is an effective Spiker that Persian can bring in on switchins such as Mareanie, Gourgeist, and Dubwool via U-turn to set up Spikes. Roselia can also utilize Sleep Powder to put shared checks like Mawile and Pawniard to sleep. Offensive entry hazard setters like Crustle and Pawniard help weaken foes early-game, and their hazards greatly aid Persian in its role as a revenge killer. Persian can form an effective VoltTurn core with teammates like Manectric, Raichu, and Raboot, all of which can cover Pokemon that can safely switch in on Persian such as Mawile, Stonjourner, and Pawniard. Silvally-Psychic can put offensive pressure on Fighting-types Persian struggles with, such as Throh, Falinks, and Hitmontop, while also threatening to set up and breaking down targets like Mawile to help Persian clean late-game. Mr. Rime can't switch in easily but can pressure Throh and Hitmontop, and its access to hazard control helps keep Persian from being overwhelmed by residual damage. Stacking other priority users like Pawniard and Falinks with Persian can form a powerful anti-setup core that takes pressure off Persian. Both examples also deter Defog with Defiant, making them good choices for teams utilizing Spikes.

Magneton.overview: Because of its good offensive typing, high Special Attack, and strong STAB options, Magneton can serve as a threatening wallbreaker that pressures defensive staples like Aromatisse and Gigalith. Analytic compensates for Magneton's middling Speed tier while also making it more difficult to switch into. Magneton can effectively take advantage of this thanks to its access to Volt Switch, putting opponents on the back foot while also generating momentum for its teammates. With the combination of Sturdy and Heavy-Duty Boots, Magneton can also act as a decent revenge killer, taking pressure off of its team against threats like Charizard and Lycanroc. However, the prevalence of Pokemon such as Lanturn, Lightning Rod Togedemaru, and Galarian Stunfisk makes walling Magneton easier for a lot of teams. Magneton's average Speed also leaves it outsped by common offensive threats like Gallade and Magmortar. Finally, due to its poor bulk, Magneton often struggles to safely switch in even on resisted hits and can't make full use of the defensive benefits that come with its Steel typing.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Tri Attack provides Magneton with neutral coverage for Lanturn and Vikavolt while still hitting Ground-types like Claydol. Teleport is another option that lets Magneton pivot out against Electric-immune Pokemon like Lightning Rod Togedemaru. Alternatively, Steel Beam manages to 2HKO even Bulk Up Scrafty on the switch if Stealth Rock is up, which Flash Cannon cannot achieve. Other pivots such as Passimian and Tsareena pair well with Magneton, since they create a momentum core and help to exert increased pressure on opposing teams. These examples also threaten nuisances like Galarian Stunfisk and offer Knock Off support, while Magneton threatens physically bulky Pokemon like Weezing. Walls like Aromatisse, Weezing, and Gigalith serve as a safety net against faster Fighting- and Fire-types like Passimian and Magmortar that force Magneton out. The former also offers Magneton vital Wish support, while the latter two can wear its switch-ins down with entry hazards, status, and, in Gigalith's case, sand. Pokemon like Sandaconda and Ribombee provide Magneton with speed control in Glare and Stun Spore, respectively, which gives it more opportunities to wallbreak by making it harder to immediately threaten out. These examples falter against Pokemon such as Trevenant, Whimsicott, and Silvally-Steel, all of which Magneton can potentially exploit.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description: Thunder Wave lets Magneton debilitate setup sweepers and wallbreakers that it can't immediately OHKO, such as Silvally-Ghost and Magmortar. Toxic can be used to gradually down wear switch-ins like Claydol and Palossand. Steel Beam is another option that always OHKOes Silvally-Fairy and +1 Ribombee. Preserving Sturdy is often easy thanks to Heavy-Duty Boots and Magneton's natural immunity to residual damage from sand, even if it needs to come in and use Volt Switch or threaten a wall like Golbat after a teammate pivots out or faints. This set fits best on offensive teams in need of both a revenge killer and a pivot. Bear in mind that Magneton doesn't need much support to function, meaning you should add it to teams that benefit from its talents rather than build around it. Magneton struggles with bulky Electric-immune Pokemon such as Lanturn, which is especially problematic given that many of its targets can easily fall back on them. As such, it appreciates having teammates like Tsareena and Whimsicott. Spikes support from Pokemon like Froslass can give Magneton an easier time revenge killing Dragon Dance Scrafty and other foes it otherwise falls short of KOing.

Exeggutor-Alola.overview: Alolan Exeggutor has an amazing Special Attack alongside a great STAB move combination and nice coverage in Flamethrower, which make it an excellent choice for either a wallbreaker or a Trick Room sweeper. Its solid bulk and defensive typing allow it to take advantage of Pokemon like Regirock and Palossand and give it an easier time setting up Trick Room. While other slow wallbreaking Dragon-types such as Guzzlord do give it competition, Alolan Exeggutor's offensive typing and ability to set up its own Trick Room manage to set it apart from them. However, Alolan Exeggutor is held back by its low Speed outside of Trick Room, weakness to common types such as Ice, and reliance on prediction due to its various switch-ins, such as Silvally-Fairy and Charizard.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: This set aims to come in as much as possible and deal raw damage with its nukes in Draco Meteor and Leaf Storm. Giga Drain is there to help Alolan Exeggutor stay healthy and allows it to be played more aggressively, while Flamethrower hits incoming Steel-types such as Togedemaru and Silvally-Steel. Although it is slow, maximum Speed investment allows Alolan Exeggutor to outspeed and KO various Pokemon before they can get a move in, such as Guzzlord and Vikavolt. Alolan Exeggutor is best at breaking past physical walls such as Regirock, defensive Mesprit, and Jellicent, but it also breaks various special walls such as Gigalith and Lanturn. Therefore, Pokemon that appreciate these walls being broken or at least weakened, like Sneasel and Scyther looking to set up and sweep late-game, work well alongside Alolan Exeggutor. Scyther, as well as other Pokemon such as Togedemaru and Mesprit, can also get Alolan Exeggutor in with U-turn.

sets.name: Trick Room
sets.description: Trick Room allows Alolan Exeggutor to take advantage of its low Speed in order to wreak havoc against many offense and even balance teams. Flamethrower is there for the Steel-types that resist Alolan Exeggutor's STAB moves, such as Silvally-Steel and Togedemaru, while also hitting Grass-types such as Tsareena without Draco Meteor's Special Attack drop. Alolan Exeggutor can be run on or off dedicated Trick Room teams. If run off of a Trick Room team, Alolan Exeggutor wants to be sent out late-game to clean up the match after Pokemon such as Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy have been weakened or taken out. In this case, it benefits from slow pivots that can get it on the field safely such as Uxie and Lanturn. On a Trick Room team, it can be used either as the late-game cleaner or as means to weaken teams and set up Trick Room for its sweeping teammates, like Wishiwashi and Marowak.

Hitmonlee.overview: With Hitmonlee's strong Attack and Unburden, it can function as a great Terrain sweeper. It has solid coverage and has passable bulk to set up with after using Electric or Grassy Seed. However, outside of Terrain teams, Hitmonlee is outclassed by other Fighting-types in the tier like Scrafty or Passimian due to Hitmonlee being reliant on Unburden to make progress. While it has the ability to set up, Hitmonlee still finds itself unable to get past Pokemon like Charizard and Aromatisse if it does not have the right coverage move.

sets.name: Terrain Sweeper
sets.description: Hitmonlee is exclusively used on Terrain teams, which, in tandem with Electric Seed or Grassy Seed, help it set up with Bulk Up more easily. Close Combat is Hitmonlee's best STAB move, as it does not run the same risk to miss as High Jump Kick does. Knock Off gives Hitmonlee coverage for Pokemon like Mesprit and Silvally-Ghost, cripples Pokemon like Weezing, and hits Flying-types if Hitmonlee is not running Stone Edge. Stone Edge allows Hitmonlee to remove Flying-types such as Charizard and Scyther with ease. Alternatively, Poison Jab gives Hitmonlee coverage for Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy. Hitmonlee requires either Pincurchin or Thwackey as a partner and therefore pairs well with other Terrain sweepers like Thievul. On Electric Terrain teams, Jolteon can pressure Flying-types for Hitmonlee so it can run Poison Jab, and Nature Power Ribombee can lure Charizard if Electric Terrain is still active. For Grassy Terrain teams, Thwackey is able to wear down Pokemon like Weezing and Charizard for Hitmonlee to break through late-game.

Weezing.overview: Weezing's physical bulk, wide utility movepool, and abilities allow it to function as a great defensive pick for teams. A pure Poison typing leaves it with only two weaknesses, one of which can be negated by Levitate, and important resistances, letting it wall Pokemon that utilize Grass- and Fighting-type moves such as Tsareena and Hitmonlee. A solid Special Attack stat and the threat of status make Weezing hard to switch into as well, and the ability to lay Toxic Spikes allows it to provide support for its team and wear down its checks. However, Weezing's low special bulk means even neutral strong special hits will take a big chunk out of its health. Weezing also has unreliable recovery, especially if it forgoes Black Sludge, since its only viable option is Pain Split. A weakness to Psychic also leaves it forced out by foes such as Mesprit and Gallade, and by those with Psychic-type coverage, such as Whimsicott and Ribombee, if it is chipped enough. Choosing Neutralizing Gas also means it struggles with Ground-types such as Palossand.

sets.name: Defensive Utility
sets.description: Weezing can function as both a wall and a supporter. Will-O-Wisp cripples against Pokemon immune to poison such as Aggron and Silvally-Steel. Taunt can be used to shut down opposing defensive Pokemon such as Gigalith and Regirock. Flamethrower allows Weezing to threaten Steel-types beyond a burn and keep Toxic Spikes up against Silvally-Steel. Neutralizing Gas sacrifices a Ground immunity to let Weezing take advantage of Pokemon that rely heavily on their abilities, such as Gurdurr, Gigalith, and Scyther, and also lets it absorb Toxic Spikes. The given EV spread allows Weezing to outspeed Pokemon like defensive Alcremie. Weezing pairs best with specially defensive Pokemon that can absorb special hits for it; these include blanket checks to special attackers, such as Gigalith and Lanturn, which enjoy Weezing soaking up Fighting- and Grass-type moves for them. Silvally-Steel has a resistance to Psychic and can Defog away entry hazards, letting Weezing take less damage from Stealth Rock and, if running Neutralizing Gas, Spikes. In return, Weezing can absorb Fighting- and, if running Levitate, Ground-type moves for it.

Tangela.overview: Tangela's solid bulk, further bolstered by Eviolite, in combination with its great ability in Regenerator makes it a great switch-in to top physical threats like Archeops, Passimian and Trevenant. Tangela also has great supportive options such as Knock Off, Leech Seed, Toxic, and Sleep Powder, which makes up for its mediocre damage output. However, Tangela is held back by its poor special bulk and bad typing, as being pure Grass leaves it vulnerable to a plethora of top Pokemon like Ribombee, Vikavolt, and Magmortar. Additionally, Tangela is very reliant on its item Eviolite, and a lot of Pokemon that it checks carry Knock Off, making Tangela less reliable of an answer to them. Furthermore, it dislikes getting poisoned by Toxic, making it less effective as a pivot.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Knock Off is a great utility move and is able to remove items such as Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon such as Centiskorch, Charizard, and Ribombee. Leech Seed allows Tangela to cripple answers like Charizard and potentially help a teammate like Regirock, although Synthesis gives it an easier time beating Pokemon like Absol in a one-on-one, which it can't reliably do when running Leech Seed. Toxic cripples defensive Pokemon better, while Sleep Powder cripples offensive Pokemon such as Passimian and allows it to bring a wallbreaker or setup sweeper in with more ease. Rock-types such as Gigalith check Fire-types such as Magmortar and Charizard. Lanturn also checks threats like Magmortar, Charizard, and Silvally-Steel that Tangela dislikes; it can also provide Heal Bell support for Tangela. In return, Tangela checks Palossand and Sandaconda for them and can bolster their health with Leech Seed. Since Tangela hates Poison-types like Golbat and Weezing, partners like Mesprit and Vikavolt are appreciated. In return, Tangela checks Absol and Togedemaru for them. Frail wallbreakers like Sneasel, Archeops, and the aforementioned Vikavolt dislike the presence of foes such as Passimian, Togedemaru, and Lycanroc, so Tangela makes for a great defensive backbone to rely on.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Mr. Mime is a great revenge killer due to its overall good Speed and Special Attack, allowing it to pick off threats such as Dubwool, Falinks, Stonjourner, and even some Silvally formes. Its access to Healing Wish allows it to bring in a weakened teammate back to full health and cure any existing status conditions, giving it more utility and team support, while Trick allows it to cripple defensive Pokemon like Type: Null and Musharna. Mr. Mime can also viably run Choice Specs to increase its wallbreaking power, though the Speed boost from Choice Scarf is normally preferred, since Mr. Mime is otherwise outsped by Silvally and Drakloak. Focus Blast or Mystical Fire can be used over a support move to allow Mr. Mime to do more damage to Steel-types like Klang and Mawile. Teleport is another option that allows Mr. Mime to provide a valuable negative-priority pivoting move and gain momentum for an offensive team.

Choice Scarf Mr. Mime itself appreciates strong wallbreakers like Life Orb Falinks, Basculin, and Silvally-Grass so that it can clean up once bulkier Pokemon like Type: Null and Mawile are weakened and faster threats like Manectric or Choice Scarf Leafeon are taken care of. These Pokemon also appreciate Mr. Mime's Healing Wish support so they can come back for a second time late-game, allowing them to be played more aggressively early in the game. Mr. Mime's generally low damage output means it also appreciates help from Spikes setters like Roselia and Crustle to wear down Pokemon it usually can't break through. Setup sweepers like Nasty Plot Gourgeist, Rock Polish Stonjourner, and Shell Smash Crustle also appreciate Mr. Mime's ability to give them a second chance at setting up to sweep with Healing Wish or shut down a defensive Pokemon like Type: Null or Pyukumuku with Trick that could keep them from sweeping. Mr. Mime also appreciates their ability to break through bulkier Pokemon like Mawile and Shiinotic for it to pick off. While Mr. Mime is decently fast, it is still outsped by Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Manectric as well as Flame Charge Silvally formes, so priority users like Hitmontop and Falinks or Speed-boosting sweepers like Rock Polish Stonjourner help take care of these threats. Defensive checks to these Pokemon like Palpitoad, Drakloak, and Pyukumuku also help Mr. Mime handle them. Alternatively, if Mr. Mime is running Trick, its ability to cripple special walls by removing their items allows other specially offensive Pokemon like Raichu and Choice Specs Glaceon to break through them better.

Scyther.overview: Scyther is a decent pivot in PU due to its decent Speed tier and high Attack. Scyther also possesses a resistance to Fighting and semi-decent bulk, granting it some defensive utility. In addition, Scyther can easily apply offensive pressure due to its Technician-boosted Dual Wingbeat and Knock Off. However, Scyther has a mediocre defensive typing with a weakness to Flying- and Rock-types, both of which are common in the tier. Scyther also has difficulty checking Fighting-types, as many of them carry either Knock Off or Stone Edge. Furthermore, Scyther has difficulty breaking through common walls even with a boost, and while it has a decent Speed tier, it is still outsped by common threats such as Archeops, Sneasel, and Ribombee. Finally, Scyther faces stiff competition from Archeops, as it provides more power to a team.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: Scyther is an excellent momentum grabber due to its offensive presence. Knock Off cripples common switch-ins such as Regirock and Weezing, making them easier to pressure. Roost is an option to extend Scyther's longevity while also taking advantage of its natural ability to force switches and passive Pokemon such as Palossand. Scyther fits nicely on VoltTurn teams due to its pivoting abilities. Lanturn works well with Scyther, as Lanturn can bring it in via a slow Volt Switch and cure its status with Heal Bell while checking Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Togedemaru that it has a hard time against. Other Volt Switch users such as Rotom and Vikavolt also pair nicely with Scyther, as they handle each other’s weaknesses while forming a VoltTurn core. Tsareena and Passimian appreciate Scyther bringing them in via U-turn against Pokemon Scyther struggles to break through, such as Regirock and Silvally-Steel.

Lanturn.overview: Lanturn has unique utility as a bulky Water-type thanks to its splendid defensive typing and great ability. This allows it to check a myriad of Pokemon such as Heliolisk, Rotom, and Charizard. It can also act as a pivot due to Volt Switch, which allows it to serve as a damage sponge to bring stronger yet more delicate wallbreakers in such as Archeops and Toxicroak that benefit from specially defensive or Grass-type Pokemon being brought in. However, it struggles switching in against Ground-types, which other bulky Water-types like Jellicent are normally able to handle; Lanturn also has to rely on passive recovery due to its lack of a reliable recovery move, which makes it unreliable as a wall for longer games.

sets.name: Bulky Pivot
sets.description: Protect is used to stall out Toxic turns and safely gain passive recovery from Leftovers. Heal Bell can be used over either Toxic or Protect to make Lanturn a cleric to assist its teammates; however, Lanturn's lack of recovery moves makes Aromatisse an overall better option for this role. The HP EVs are used to gain an extra HP from Leftovers, and the Special Defense EVs are used to never get 4HKOed by Heliolisk's Hyper Voice after stalling with Protect for Leftovers recovery. The Speed EVs let Lanturn outspeed maximum Speed, neutral-natured base 40 Pokemon such as Rhydon, and the Special Attack EVs are for Lanturn to OHKO Rhydon with Scald. Defensively, Lanturn needs support from Pokemon that can take on Grass- and Ground-type threats like Whimsicott and Sandaconda. This makes Pokemon such as Charizard, Whimsicott, and Weezing solid partners. Lanturn can also support wallbreakers such as Gourgeist-S and Lycanroc that can offensively pressure its main checks, while it supports them defensively and safely brings them in via Volt Switch.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description: Assault Vest allows Lanturn to switch into special attacking threats such as Heliolisk and Magmortar without sacrificing power. Hydro Pump is an option over Scald, allowing it useful rolls such as a guaranteed 2HKO on specially defensive Claydol with an accuracy and utility tradeoff. Discharge can cripple common Pokemon like Mesprit, while Dazzling Gleam 2HKOes Guzzlord without an Assault Vest and Bulk Up Scrafty. Psybeam is a niche option that allows Lanturn to OHKO Toxicroak, which is a threat that can freely switch into Scald. The Speed EVs are used for maximum Speed, neutral-natured base 50 Pokemon and lower such as Aggron and Perrserker. Pokemon like Tsareena appreciate Lanturn being able to wall their checks like Charizard, and it is also defensively supported by Pokemon such as Palossand and Aromatisse that switch in on physical threats like Aggron and non-Gunk Shot Passimian that take advantage of it. Moreover, Aromatisse can further support Lanturn with Wish.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description:
Togetic's unique dual defensive typing paired with an Eviolite allows it to check common Fighting-types like Throh and Falinks, Dragon-types such as Vibrava and Drakloak, and Grass-types like Tangela and Leafeon. Defog is the primary reason to use Togetic; with its decent coverage, Togetic pressures our Defiant users, Falinks and Pawniard, pretty efficiently while still defeating Stealth Rock setters like Palpitoad and Carkol. Togetic’s passive nature is mitigated by the use of Thunder Wave, as offensive Pokemon that try to take advantage of it like Mr. Rime, Glaceon, Silvally-Rock, or Stonjourner do not appreciate being slowed down. Flamethrower, with an alternative spread of 248 HP / 176 Def / 84 Spe, can be used to outspeed non-invested Mawile; paired with Serene Grace, Flamethrower has higher odds of burning the foe. Heal Bell is an option that gives your team a cleric, and an option to more freely use Defog on and defeat Stealth Rock users that run Toxic, like Palpitoad.

Togetic is passive in nature, so use it on balance or semi-stall teams, specifically which have a solid defensive backbone that can handle Ice-types like Mr. Rime, Glaceon, and Lapras, Rock-types such as Crustle and Stonjourner, and Electric-types like Raichu and Manectric. Palpitoad and Hippopotas are spectacular paired with Togetic, as they can defeat most Electric- and Rock-types that scare out Togetic. Pokemon that appreciate entry hazard removal are nice partners, especially those that can check Ice-types and appreciate the Fighting resistance and Heal Bell support that Togetic offers like Lapras and Glaceon, which pressure Pokemon that wall Togetic, like Mareanie and Roselia, respectively. Musharna and Beheeyem can weaken or KO Poison-types, giving Togetic a much easier time clicking Defog, while Togetic's Fairy typing is useful for Dark-types like Thievul, making these Pokemon have natural synergy and a strong defensive core against Fighting-types. Because Togetic despises losing its Eviolite, Knock Off absorbers are perfect teammates; these include Silvally formes, Throh, Mawile, Colbur Berry Musharna, and Dubwool. Dubwool in particular is a good partner for Togetic; it counters Pawniard trying to exploit Defog and acts as a Rock check for Togetic. Klang and Type: Null are also notable, as Klang and Type: Null can act as wincons that can check Ice-types that threaten Togetic, while Togetic handles the Fighting-types and Dubwool that Klang and Type: Null do not like dealing with.

Sneasel.overview: Sneasel is a strong offensive threat in PU thanks to its high Speed that allows it to outpace major threats such as Archeops and near-unresisted STAB move combination in Knock Off and Triple Axel, which are powerful enough to make up for Sneasel's lacking Attack stat. Sneasel can further improve its damage output with Swords Dance or Choice Band. However, even with these options, Sneasel can struggle to break through walls like Weezing and Aromatisse. Sneasel's bulk is very low, making it difficult to switch into even the most passive defensive Pokemon, such as Palossand. It also doesn't help that not running Heavy-Duty Boots leaves Sneasel extremely vulnerable to all forms of entry hazards, while running it leaves Sneasel somewhat weaker and more vulnerable to status. Sneasel also faces competition from other fast revenge killers such as Archeops and Whimsicott, which have more switch-in opportunities and pivoting. Nevertheless, nothing in the tier can rival Sneasel's combination of typing, Speed, and powerful STAB combination.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Due to Sneasel's weakness to Stealth Rock and susceptibility to all other entry hazards, Heavy-Duty Boots is the primary option for its held item. However, Life Orb can be used for an easier time sweeping, and Lum Berry gives Sneasel a one-time out from being crippled by status from the likes of Weezing and Jellicent. Sneasel rarely wants to directly switch into attacks, so it is best brought in as a revenge killer or through pivots such as Silvally-Fairy and Uxie. Silvally-Fairy is also able to remove hazards, while Uxie is able to set Stealth Rock up, and both can also check Fighting-types like Passimian, which can cause trouble for Sneasel. These Fighting-types, as well as defensive threats like Weezing and Silvally-Steel, should be taken out or greatly weakened for Sneasel before it starts setting up. Wallbreakers such as Charizard and Archeops are ideal for this role. Spikes setters and Rocky Helmet users such as Qwilfish and Druddigon are also ideal for dealing chip damage to Choice Scarf users such as Passimian and Togedemaru, ideally putting them into range of Sneasel's +2 Ice Shard before it starts setting up.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band gives Sneasel a good amount of raw power to spam its STAB moves. Low Kick provides coverage for various Pokemon that would take longer for Sneasel to wear down, such as Regirock and Silvally-Steel. Similarly to its Swords Dance set, Sneasel has difficulty hard switching in and is therefore best brought in as a revenge killer or through pivots such as Lanturn and defensive Mesprit. Because full control over the entry hazard game is difficult, Sneasel will either want very effective entry hazard removers or setters. Capable entry hazard removers such as Silvally-Fairy and Whimsicott give Sneasel more chances to wallbreak and are better for teams that can bring it in more frequently. Tsareena is an effective Rapid Spin user in some matchups and also a powerful wallbreaker in its own right, capable of wearing down many defensive Pokemon such as Weezing in conjuction with Sneasel. Entry hazard setters such as Ferroseed and Qwilfish make Sneasel more devastating each time it comes in but tend to also allow Stealth Rock on Sneasel's side of the field, limiting its switch-ins. Sweepers and cleaners such as Quiver Dance Ribombee and Dragon Dance Scrafty also make for good teammates, as they appreciate Sneasel's ability to deal heavy damage to opposing walls.

Hitmontop.overview: Hitmontop's solid movepool and priority allow it to carve itself a niche in PU as a Fighting-type with both defensive utility and power. It has decent bulk and can either sponge hits with Assault Vest or amplify its power with Life Orb. However, Hitmontop is often competing with faster Fighting-types that are not reliant on priority like Choice Scarf Passimian. It is also vulnerable to being worn down throughout the game, especially when running Life Orb. Generally, Hitmontop will only be on specific team structures for its unique combination of power and priority.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: Triple Axel targets Flying-resistant foes like Altaria and Claydol. Thief allows Hitmontop to have some utility after absorbing Knock Off. Stone Edge allows Hitmontop to OHKO Charizard and Ribombee. Close Combat is a viable alternative move that provides more power, which makes it easier to break through Pokemon like Regirock. Fake Out allows Hitmontop to get Pokemon such as Omastar and Jolteon into Mach Punch range. Bullet Punch is an alternative coverage move to pick off weakened Froslass and Ribombee, but it can be difficult to fit. Assault Vest lets Hitmontop stomach special attacks from wallbreakers like Magmortar and check them. Heavy-Duty Boots gives Hitmontop more sustainability and lets it better support its team with Rapid Spin. Life Orb cuts into Hitmontop's longevity but gives it an easier time picking off Pokemon such as Silvally-Steel with the combination of Fake Out and Mach Punch. The given Speed investment allows Hitmontop to outspeed Silvally formes after Rapid Spin. 172 Speed EVs can be used on Stone Edge variants to outspeed Charizard after Rapid Spin. Due to how easily Hitmontop gets worn down, it appreciates Wish support from Pokemon like Aromatisse. In return, Hitmontop is able to check Pokemon like Aggron and Absol. Regirock and Weezing appreciate Hitmontop being able to pivot into special attacks from Pokemon such as Heliolisk. Spikes setters like Froslass and Garbodor pair nicely with Hitmontop, as they wear Pokemon down into priority range. In return, these Pokemon appreciate Hitmontop providing Rapid Spin support. Absol can weaken shared checks like Regirock with Knock Off and pressure Ghost-types like Cofagrigus.

sets.name: Toxic Orb Attacker
sets.description:
Galarian Linoone is a reliable revenge killer thanks to its Quick Feet ability and can hit decently hard with its status-boosted Facade. However, it can be worn down quickly between Toxic and entry hazards. Galarian Linoone is able to support teammates with its pivoting capability through Parting Shot. Knock Off lets it cripple Pokemon such as Type: Null and Tangela that rely on their items. Protect allows Galarian Linoone to safely activate its Toxic Orb and Quick Feet, block First Impression from Falinks and Fraxure, and scout against Choice item users such as Choice Scarf Golduck and Manectric. Galarian Linoone's Speed tier and ability to switch moves set it apart from other fast revenge killers like Choice Scarf Unfezant and Lycanroc-N. A set using Double-Edge over Facade with Eviolite gives it more bulk in exchange for the ability to immediately take advantage of Quick Feet and becomes more of a fast pivot than a revenge killer.

Wallbreakers such as Appletun and Marowak appreciate the ability to come in safely and pressure Pokemon that Galarian Linoone can pivot on such as Mawile and Stunfisk. In return, Galarian Linoone is able to pick off Pokemon weakened by them. Since Galarian Linoone is prone to being taken advantage of by Competitive and Defiant users such as Wigglytuff, Pawniard, and Falinks, checks to these Pokemon like Gourgeist for Wigglytuff and Galarian Rapidash for Pawniard and Falinks are needed. Galarian Linoone can also form a pivoting core with Manectric, Golduck, Morpeko, Raboot, or Boltund to wear down the opposing team. Parting Shot's Attack and Special Attack drops can also help setup sweepers like Galarian Rapidash and Drifblim have an easier time setting up. As Galarian Linoone will be frequently entering the field, entry hazard removal from Mr. Rime or Morpeko is appreciated too. Mareanie and Stunfisk can also pivot into Fighting-type moves such as Hitmonchan's Mach Punch for Galarian Linoone.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Solrock is a Stealth Rock setter that acts as a physical wall thanks to its decent Defense and access to Will-O-Wisp and a reliable recovery move, making it a good check to some physical attackers such as Persian and Stonjourner. It is also notable for having a decent matchup against spinners such as Hitmontop and Galarian Mr. Mime depending on its coverage. However, Solrock suffers from competition with other Stealth Rock setters such as Mawile and Palpitoad, both of which have a better typing and are easier to fit on teams. Mawile has access to Intimidate and plenty of really good resistances such as Ice, Grass, and Flying while Palpitoad has two great immunities in Electric and Water. Rock Slide gives Solrock a better matchup against common entry hazard removers like Mr. Rime, whereas Zen Headbutt is another option that helps against Fighting-types such as Throh and Falinks. Toxic can be an option over Will-O-Wisp to wear down bulkier Pokemon like Gourgeist-XL and Beheeyem, but in a lot of cases, Solrock needs the opposing Pokemon burned to check it easily. Colbur Berry can be used to check Throh, which it can't cripple with Will-O-Wisp, more easily. However, Solrock otherwise prefers the passive recovery from Leftovers.

Solrock struggles a lot against Dark-types such as Pawniard and Thievul, so Fighting-types like Throh, Falinks, and Hitmontop make really good teammates for it. They also benefit from Solrock's unique typing, since they tend to struggle against Psychic- and Flying-types such as Defog Silvally-Psychic and Vespiquen that Solrock has no trouble checking. Falinks can offensively check Swords Dance Silvally-Psychic and Ludicolo variants thanks to First Impression. Offensive Grass- and Water-types such as Silvally-Grass and Basculin can easily pressure Solrock, so bulky Grass-types such as Gourgeist and Roselia are recommended teammates for it. Solrock can also switch into Fire- and Flying-types such as Raboot and Vespiquen for Roselia and Gourgeist. Although Solrock has good Defense, its Special Defense is bad, so special walls such as Dusclops and Type: Null work well as teammates, since both of them can switch fairly well into wallbreakers that pressure Solrock like Ludicolo and Glaceon.

Claydol.overview: Claydol's unique qualities, movepool, and typing allow it to function as an interesting form of role compression on teams. It has access to Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, making it a solid choice for either a Stealth Rock setter or a defensive spinner, although it cannot threaten most Ghost-types. Its typing and Levitate give it important resistances to Fighting-, Psychic-, and Rock-type moves, letting it pivot into these moves from Pokemon such as Passimian, Mesprit, and Aggron, as well as two important immunities to Electric and Ground; these make it a stop to Volt Switch pivots and Pokemon locked into Earthquake in a pinch, as it fares badly against most of them otherwise. However, Claydol is very passive, heavily relying on Toxic to maintain a presence. It is forced to choose between two STAB moves that are exploitable, meaning it can struggle against foes such as Golbat and Togedemaru depending on the move it chooses. Its typing is also a double-edged sword, with weaknesses to Grass, Dark, Water, and Bug, making it easy to exploit by Pokemon such as Tsareena and Absol, and many of the Pokemon it would like to check can run these moves. Claydol also lacks recovery if it forgoes Leftovers, meaning it can be hard to check what it wants to over a long match.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Psychic has solid neutral coverage as Claydol's STAB move, letting it chip Flying-types such as Archeops and Charizard, but makes it harder to threaten Dark-types. Scorching Sands can be chosen as its STAB move due to its ability to spread burns and hit Dark-types, but it loses to Pokemon such as Golbat and Weezing. Teleport allows Claydol to gain momentum against Pokemon it forces out such as Choice-locked Togedemaru. Alternatively, Protect and Leftovers give Claydol more recovery, increase Toxic damage, and scout opposing Choice-locked Pokemon. However, this gives it a worse matchup against Knock Off users such as Absol and Passimian due to the lack of Colbur Berry. The Speed investment is to guarantee outspeeding fully invested base 80s after a Rapid Spin, such as Gallade and Mesprit, crippling them with a Toxic before they can respond. Claydol likes to have defensive support from Pokemon that can handle special attackers like Rotom, Charizard, and Basculin. Lanturn can take hits from all of them and cripple them with Toxic, and Assault Vest Lanturn specifically can soak up general special hits for Claydol. Ferroseed is another option, functioning as a Toxic sponge that can also check Grass- and Water-types. In return, Claydol can reduce the chip damage Lanturn takes with Rapid Spin and deal with Ground-types such as Sandaconda for both of them. Claydol often best fits on more defensive teams due to its lack of recovery, supportive capabilities, and lacking offensive presence; as such, it appreciates the cleric and Wish support Pokemon such as Aromatisse and Audino can give it.

Absol.overview: Absol is a great wallbreaker in the PU metagame thanks to a sky-high Attack stat, a spammable STAB option in Knock Off, and options to boost its Attack in Choice Band and Swords Dance. Access to priority in Sucker Punch, which is especially potent with Swords Dance, makes it harder to revenge kill. Its wide coverage options to hit standard Dark-type checks, like Iron Tail and Close Combat for Aromatisse and Regirock, and an extremely strong STAB Knock Off are its main draws over otherwise similar Pokemon such as Sneasel and Silvally-Dark. Unfortunately, Absol's poor bulk, few resistances, and weaknesses to common Fighting- and Bug-type moves in the tier leave it with little defensive utility. This means Absol struggles to get in, and due to its middling Speed tier as well as Sucker Punch being easy to work around, it often gets forced out.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: The fourth move of choice depends on what Absol wants to deal with. Iron Tail takes care of bulky Fairy-types such as Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy; however, Psycho Cut lets it 2HKO Weezing after Stealth Rock and does significant damage to Fighting-types like Hitmontop. Justified is run in order to punish Knock Offs from Pokemon such as Malamar and Scrafty; however, Super Luck means Psycho Cut will critically hit half of the time. A Jolly nature is chosen to ensure Absol can outspeed Jolly Hitmontop and Tsareena, but an Adamant nature hits harder. Absol has trouble getting onto the field, so slow pivots such as Uxie can help with that. They also help by baiting in Absol's prey, foes such as Rotom and Palossand, making it even easier for Absol to take something down. Fighting-types such as Passimian and Gurdurr appreciate Absol's ability to weaken Poison- and Fairy-types with its coverage, making it easier for them to sweep. Absol appreciates Fighting-type checks and Pokemon that can pivot into U-turn, such as Aromatisse and Weezing, as they can punish these Pokemon that Absol dislikes.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Iron Tail takes out Fairy-types such as Aromatisse, while Close Combat takes care of Rock-types such as Regirock and Dark-types such as Scrafty. Play Rough can be used as a middle ground to hit Fighting-types such as Passimian and Hitmontop on a switch-in while hitting Fairy-types harder than Close Combat, but lacks the higher power of Iron Tail or Close Combat. Life Orb is preferred, but Black Glasses gives better longevity and the ability to bluff a Choice Band set. Justified is run to punish Knock Offs from Pokemon like Uxie. However, Super Luck, when used with Psycho Cut, results in a critical hit half of the time. Sticky Webs support is heavily appreciated due to Absol's middling Speed tier, so setters like Ribombee and Vikavolt are great partners for it. Vikavolt also breaks through physical walls such as Regirock. On bulkier teams, slow pivots such as Lanturn can help Swords Dance Absol wallbreak or sweep a team by slowly wearing down its checks whilst providing setup opportunities. Hazard setters such as Palossand also help Swords Dance Absol by moving many faster threats into the range of a boosted Sucker Punch, like Silvally-Fairy. Offensive sweepers such as Quiver Dance Ribombee appreciate Absol's wallbreaking, as it makes it easier for them to clean late-game.

Regirock.overview: Regirock's incredible physical bulk, typing, and access to Stealth Rock make it a premier physical wall in the tier. It can check a multitude of threats, like Archeops, Sneasel, Togedemaru, and Scyther, giving it multiple opportunities to set Stealth Rock reliably. However, it struggles against common wallbreakers like Gallade and can get overwhelmed rather quickly due to its lack of reliable recovery. Lastly, it suffers from competition from Gigalith, which can switch into threats like Charizard more reliably thanks to Sand Stream giving it better special bulk.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description: Thanks to its typing and splendid physical bulk, Regirock makes for a sturdy Stealth Rock setter capable of dishing out solid damage thanks to Body Press. The given EV spread allows Regirock to always avoid the 2HKO from Tsareena, Choice Band Aggron, and Choice Scarf Passimian, while Clear Body lets it block Parting Shot. Rock Blast allows Regirock to break Substitute and Focus Sash from Pokemon like Rotom-F and lead Archeops, while Stone Edge hits consistently harder. Toxic gives Regirock a way to cripple walls like Palossand and Jellicent, whereas Thunder Wave can be used to cripple more offensive threats such as Whimsicott. Partners that can take on special attackers like Magneton and Magmortar that Regirock struggles against are appreciated. Lanturn stands out as a solid option, being able to further support Regirock with Heal Bell. Answers to Fighting- and Grass-types like Passimian and Tsareena are also appreciated; this makes Weezing a stellar partner. Charizard is another great teammate, and it appreciates Regirock checking threats like Archeops.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Heavy-Duty Boots lets Vespiquen circumvent its 4x Stealth Rock weakness, making it a viable option for checking Grass- and Fighting-types like Silvally-Grass, Leafeon, Throh, Falinks, and Hitmontop and as a slow pivot with U-turn. Roost gives Vespiquen a reliable recovery option, and allows for more chances to stall moves like Silvally-Psychic's Multi-Attack with Pressure. Defog and Pressure pair nicely together, as this means you can PP stall Toxic Spikes and Spikes from Mareanie and Roselia for the entirety of the game. Alternatively, Toxic Spikes cripples foes, while Aromatherapy lets Vespiquen function as a cleric. Vespiquen’s Speed alongside U-turn is excellent for slow pivoting, giving you ample opportunities to bring in wallbreakers. Air Slash makes it easier to defeat Gourgeist-XL that have burned Vespiquen, but Acrobatics is an option to have a strong STAB move if Throh or Leafeon choose to remove Vespiquen's item with Knock Off.

Vespiquen fits best on bulky offense and balance teams that can deal with Defog deterrents like Falinks and Pawniard, so Silvally-Electric, Dubwool, Hitmontop, and Throh are excellent teammates, as they not only check Pawniard and act as Knock Off absorbers, the latter two are also Rock-type checks. Palpitoad is very notable as a partner; it resists Rock, checks Pawniard, and handles Fire- and Electric-types like Raboot and Manectric, while Vespiquen checks Grass-types in return. Vespiquen's reliance on Heavy-Duty Boots means it is not optimal to have its item removed by Knock Off unless you are using Acrobatics, so Knock Off absorbers like Rocky Helmet Mawile, Silvally formes, Colbur Berry Musharna, and Throh make it easier for Vespiquen to not be affected by Stealth Rock damage. Strong wallbreakers that can break Rock- and Ice-types, like Falinks, Silvally formes, and Stonjourner, appreciate the safety from slow U-turn pivoting; Vespiquen benefits from the removal of such Pokemon, since it makes it much easier for it to use Defog. Vespiquen does not appreciate Ice-type Pokemon like Mr. Rime, Glaceon, and Lapras; Type: Null, Mr. Rime, Klang, Throh, and Lapras are fine options for mitigating this weakness, using Toxic, pivoting, or phasing them out to deal with them.

Magmortar.overview: Magmortar is an extremely threatening wallbreaker in PU thanks to its incredible coverage and very high Special Attack. These allow it to break through many special walls that aim to check Fire-types such as Regirock and Jellicent. Magmortar also has a decent Speed stat, with a Timid nature allowing it to outspeed base 80 Speed Pokemon such as non-Choice Scarf Mesprit. However, Magmortar is still outrun by many common threats such as Basculin and Silvally. Its merely fine Speed combined with its lacking physical bulk make Magmortar relatively simple to revenge kill compared to Charizard, which has much more long-term potential. Finally, Magmortar is forced to choose between being extremely vulnerable to all entry hazards and giving up a boosting item.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description: Thunderbolt hits Water- and Flying-types such as Jellicent and Charizard. Focus Blast hits Rock-types such as Gigalith and Regirock as well as Scrafty. The last slot is very customizable depending on your team's needs: Scorching Sands gives Magmortar a better matchup against Lanturn and opposing Magmortar while also being a safer way to hit Rock-types. Taunt prevents recovery from the likes of Jellicent and Scrafty as well as Stealth Rock from setters like Druddigon in a pinch. Toxic is a good source of chip damage versus walls such as Jellicent and Gigalith. Overheat is a powerful nuke for Choice Specs Magmortar. Flame Charge is another option to turn Magmortar into a late-game cleaner, although it should only be run with Heavy-Duty Boots and a Timid nature. Magmortar can switch into a few resisted hits from Pokemon such as Whimsicott and Silvally-Steel, but it is easily worn down and better brought in by pivots such as Lanturn and Passimian. It can also switch into predicted U-turns from Pokemon like Togedemaru and Archeops to fish for burn with Flame Body, although this can be risky. Setup sweepers such as Scrafty and Quiver Dance Ribombee make for great teammates that can effectively exploit Magmortar's breaking power. Magmortar greatly appreciates entry hazard removers if it opts to not run Heavy-Duty Boots: Silvally-Fairy and Rotom are good Defoggers that can also bring Magmortar in via pivoting.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Choice Specs Glaceon is one of PU's scariest wallbreakers, capable of putting immense pressure on even some of the tier's best special walls in Throh and Type: Null as a result of its sheer power. Freeze-Dry allows Glaceon to threaten Ice-resistant Water-types like Pyukumuku and Corsola, and it's also Glaceon's best option against Lapras. Shadow Ball allows Glaceon to OHKO Galarian Mr. Mime and threaten specially defensive Mr. Rime. It also hits Klang and opposing Glaceon harder than any other move Glaceon can viably run. Water Pulse targets Carkol, though it doesn't have much use outside of that. Frost Breath can allow Glaceon to get past bulky Calm Mind and Cosmic Power users like Musharna and Gothitelle in a pinch, but the move is virtually useless outside of this one purpose and cuts into Glaceon's already limited coverage. A Timid nature can be used to outspeed Adamant Falinks and Choice Band Fraxure as well as Speed tie with offensive Roselia. Glaceon could opt to use Choice Scarf to act as a revenge killer rather than a wallbreaker. Although this allows Glaceon to take care of +1 Adamant Fraxure and circumvent typical offensive checks like Silvally-Grass and Raichu, such a set severely reduces Glaceon's power and faces serious competition from Mr. Rime and Galarian Mr. Mime due to their higher Speed tiers, better coverage, and access to Healing Wish.

Glaceon's low Speed and poor defensive typing make it very easy to offensively pressure, so it appreciates having bulky teammates to fall back on in the face of faster Fire-, Fighting-, and Rock-types. Vibrava gives Glaceon an easier time switching in by removing entry hazards with Defog and generating momentum with U-turn. It's worth noting that a lot of Pokemon that Vibrava baits in and pivots out against, like Gloom and Togetic, find themselves easily exploited by Glaceon. Mareanie absorbs Toxic Spikes upon switching in, can wear teams down with its own Toxic Spikes, and also softens up bulky foes that depend on their item, like Type: Null and Lapras, with Knock Off. Although Glaceon is strong, it lacks the coverage to bypass dedicated Ice-type answers such as Munchlax and Klang. Wallbreakers like Mawile, Hitmontop, and Flame Orb Throh help to remedy this issue, and they appreciate Glaceon taking on physical walls like Mareanie, Shiinotic, and Gourgeist-XL. Mawile also provides Stealth Rock support to put further pressure on teams, while Hitmontop removes entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Glaceon has an easier time breaking through teams with Spikes support, essentially 2HKOing Type: Null after Stealth Rock and three layers of Spikes. Roselia is a great Spikes setter, capable of incapacitating foes like Klang with Sleep Powder and making them easier for Glaceon to overwhelm. Pivots like Manectric and Silvally-Bug can give Glaceon more opportunities to switch in, with both examples doubling as late-game sweepers that can exploit the holes that Glaceon leaves in teams earlier on. These pivots can annoy Pokemon like Lapras and Pawniard, while Glaceon can threaten Palpitoad and Carkol.

sets.name: Cleric
sets.description:
Because of its decent bulk and near-unique access to both Wish and Heal Bell, Glaceon can serve as a cleric for balance teams. Freeze-Dry is used instead of Ice Beam to hit foes like Lapras and Seaking harder. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Glaceon from being worn down by entry hazards, which allows it to more easily switch around and better preserve the health of it and its teammates. This immunity to entry hazards, alongside Glaceon's higher Special Attack and natural defenses, helps to separate it from Togetic, another cleric that similarly has access to Wish and Heal Bell. Although Glaceon has higher Defense than Special Defense, its poor defensive typing is easily exploited by many of the tier's physical attackers, including Mawile, Falinks, and Silvally-Rock. There are fewer specially offensive Pokemon that can do the same, and opting for a specially defensive set provides defensive teams with a secondary check to threats like Ludicolo and opposing Glaceon.

Stunfisk and physically defensive Mawile appreciate having their lack of reliable recovery mitigated by Wish support, and in return, they can absorb Knock Off and check threats that Glaceon is vulnerable to, such as Pawniard and Stonjourner. Pyukumuku can also absorb Knock Off as well as wall setup sweepers like Falinks and Crustle that threaten Glaceon thanks to Unaware. In return, Glaceon can relieve Pyukumuku of any potential status conditions, which is especially useful for Rest variants. Stronger special attackers like Beheeyem and Raichu are capable of overwhelming Glaceon, meaning that it should never be the only special wall on balance teams. Other specially bulky Pokemon such as Type: Null, Dusclops, Vibrava, and Munchlax make for great partners because of this, with Rest allowing all three examples to soak up status conditions for Glaceon as well. Glaceon allows these examples to rely less on Rest by providing them with Wish support. Checks to Fighting-types are useful partners, since they can often switch into Glaceon with ease. Mareanie is a notable example, since it can consistently check Fighting-types thanks to both Recover and Regenerator, further wears teams down through Scald and either Toxic or Toxic Spikes, takes pressure off of Glaceon's team by absorbing Toxic Spikes, and stops setup sweepers like Falinks in their tracks with Haze.

Gallade.overview: Gallade makes for a potent wallbreaker with its raw strength, coverage, and decent Speed tier. It does a great job at dismantling slower teams, as it can threaten balance staples with its STAB moves, such as Regirock and Weezing. Gallade is able to distinguish itself from other Fighting-types like Passimian and Sawk with its immediate power, secondary STAB, and ability to boost with Swords Dance. However, its Speed tier still leaves much to be desired, as it can easily be pressured by offensive Pokemon like Archeops and Charizard. Gallade finds itself competing with other Fighting-type wallbreakers like Scrafty that are weaker initially but have more defensive utility.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Gallade is able to bolster its naturally high Attack with Life Orb to easily muscle past Pokemon like Gigalith without the need for hazards. Swords Dance elevates its power even further, helping net OHKOs on bulky Pokemon like Weezing once boosted, while generally being harder to switch into. It also provides the necessary strength to get past Palossand and Aromatisse. Lum Berry provides more setup opportunities against status users, such as Gigalith and Regirock. Sticky Web support from Pokemon like Ribombee, Galvantula, and Vikavolt allows Gallade to outspeed Pokemon like Silvally-Steel and Lycanroc. These Sticky Web setters are also able to pivot Gallade into Pokemon such as Gigalith and Togedemaru. Gallade's middling Speed tier makes it rather easy for it to be checked by common Pokemon like Charizard and Silvally-Fairy, so Gallade appreciates having a defensive backbone with Pokemon like Druddigon and Sandaconda to fall back on. Gallade's average bulk can be mitigated with pivots like Togedemaru and Whimsicott to get it in safely on Pokemon like Weezing.

Froslass.overview: Froslass makes for a capable wallbreaker thanks to its usable Attack and great Speed tier combined with its unique typing. It also has access to utility moves such as Trick and Spikes, allowing it to cripple and overwhelm its answers; it can even run a dedicated Spikes set, although it becomes much weaker without a boosting item. However, its below average Attack often leaves it over-reliant on its own Spikes to get past defensive behemoths like Regirock, while its typing and bulk leave it easily revenge killed by faster threats such as Lycanroc, Choice Scarf Togedemaru, and Sneasel as well as priority moves like Sucker Punch and Accelrock.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Triple Axel is a strong, albeit unreliable, STAB move. Icicle Crash is an option, as it's more reliable despite being weaker; it also avoids Rough Skin and Flame Body from the likes of Druddigon and Coalossal. Trick allows Froslass to cripple its answers such as Scrafty and Aromatisse, while Ice Shard allows it to revenge kill foes like Ribombee. Despite seeming odd on a set using a Choice item, Spikes lets Froslass take advantage of the many Pokemon it forces out. Froslass's subpar bulk means it appreciates being brought in via partners like Galarian Articuno and Passimian; Both can also act as a Defog deterrent, and they both appreciate the Spikes Froslass sets. Pokemon like Quiver Dance Ribombee and Dragon Dance Charizard have an easier time cleaning late-game after Froslass has weakened down walls such as Regirock, Aromatisse, and Silvally-Steel.

sets.name: Spikes
sets.description: Froslass's great Speed and typing make it a potent Spikes setter, as it's capable of pressuring common spinners such as Tsareena. Taunt prevents Pokemon like Miltank from recovering and also allows Froslass to keep its Spikes on the field against Defog users like Silvally-Fairy. Wallbreakers like Magmortar and Archeops greatly appreciate the Spikes Froslass sets, as it gives them an easier time breaking through Gigalith and Regirock, respectively. They can also both pressure common Defog users that Froslass struggles against like Silvally-Steel and Charizard. Pokemon like Regirock, Weezing, and Lanturn can switch into threats such as Lycanroc, Choice Scarf Passimian, and Togedemaru that force out Froslass, respectively.

Rotom.overview: Rotom is a quite versatile Pokemon thanks to its solid typing both offensively and defensively, great Speed, and decent movepool. These traits allow it to perform well as either a Choice Scarf user or a Defogger. Electric / Ghost is a near unresisted typing, bar some exceptions such as Drampa and Shiftry, all of which can be pivoted out against with Volt Switch. Defensively, Rotom resists or is immune to various common attacks from Pokemon such as Scyther and Passimian, although has to watch out for common coverage moves such as Knock Off. Rotom's Speed allows it to outspeed threatening breakers such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and Magmortar and for its Choice Scarf set to outspeed other common Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Mesprit. There are other Electric- and Ghost-types that give it competition as a Choice Scarf user, such as Togedemaru with its higher Speed and valuable Steel typing, and Haunter with its higher Speed and Special Attack alongside support moves such as Destiny Bond. However, Rotom's unique type combination and access to both Trick and Volt Switch make it a great option over the other two.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf allows Rotom to utilize its solid Speed to outspeed various other Choice Scarf users, such as Passimian and Mesprit, as well as gain momentum with Volt Switch. While Trick is run to cripple specially defensive Pokemon that may try to switch in on Rotom, such as Lanturn and Gigalith, it can also be used to potentially put a stop to bulky setup Pokemon such as Scrafty and Aromatisse. Rotom is best used as a revenge killer or brought in by slow pivots such as defensive Mesprit and defensive Silvally-Fairy, which furthermore form a solid VoltTurn core with it. Wallbreakers such as Tsareena and Magmortar benefit from being brought in through Rotom's Volt Switch.

sets.name: Defog
sets.description: Rotom can serve as a solid Defog user with its good matchup against various entry hazard setters such as Mesprit and Palossand. Furthermore, it is able to cripple various other hazard setters such as Gigalith and Druddigon with Will-O-Wisp. Will-O-Wisp also powers up Hex, which should only be run alongside it. Thunderbolt is an option for the last slot if you want to give Rotom more of an offensive presence, although Pain Split is an option to increase Rotom's longevity that pairs well with its low HP stat. Colbur Berry allows for Rotom to better check Fighting-types and other Knock Off users, such as Passimian and Scyther, but Heavy-Duty Boots is a secondary option so it can take no damage from Stealth Rock. While Rotom does have a nice defensive typing, it is recommended to not switch it into attacks too many times, as it is easily worn down with its only okay bulk, especially without Pain Split. Pokemon that are easily worn down by entry hazards, such as Silvally-Steel and Passimian, appreciate Rotom's hazard removal.

Uxie.overview: Uxie stands out as a great pivot in PU thanks to its natural Speed, bulk, and support options. Uxie's Speed allows it to pivot out with U-turn before Pokemon like Aggron can otherwise muscle past it. Uxie is able to check weaker physical attackers such as Lycanroc and Archeops and potentially cripple them with Thunder Wave or Knock Off, but it can be worn down due to the lack of reliable recovery. Uxie also faces heavy competition from Mesprit, which offers more utility in Healing Wish and is less vulnerable to bulky setup sweepers like Scrafty and Sandaconda.

sets.name: Defensive Stealth Rock
sets.description: Uxie is able to consistently set Stealth Rock with its natural bulk and pivot against entry hazard removers that it cannot do much to like Claydol and Silvally-Steel. Knock Off is helpful for crippling other passive Pokemon like Gigalith and Aromatisse. Alternatively, Thunder Wave is a great tool for stopping setup sweepers that do not mind Psychic such as Mesprit and Silvally-Fairy, while also targeting Defoggers like Charizard that force Uxie out. Memento is also an option to support frailer setup sweepers such as Ribombee and Absol. Colbur Berry allows Uxie to stay in against opposing Knock Off users like Absol and hinder it with Thunder Wave or pivot out and get some chip damage. Leftovers is another option to let Uxie stay healthy, as it has no consistent recovery of its own. While Uxie's bulk is well-rounded, it can struggle with stronger special attackers like Ribombee and Charizard due to the lack of Special Defense investment. Specially defensive Pokemon such as Silvally-Steel and Lanturn can help cover for Uxie so it will not be overwhelmed by these special attackers. Uxie is able to take advantage of U-turn to get wallbreakers like Absol and Aggron in safely or form pivot cores with Pokemon such as Passimian and Rotom. Aromatisse helps Uxie against Dark-types like Absol and Scrafty and can provide Wish support and Uxie can pressure Weezing in return.

Mesprit.overview: Mesprit stands out as by far the most versatile Pokemon in PU thanks to its solid stat distribution, excellent ability in Levitate, and wide support movepool with moves such as U-turn, Healing Wish, Trick, Nasty Plot, and Stealth Rock. Mesprit is extremely good at role compression and can fulfill a variety of different needs for your team, although its counters rarely differ too much based on the set. While Mesprit is a solid wallbreaker and has the speed to beat out slower offensive and defensive staples like Tsareena and Weezing, it's still outpaced by a large portion of the metagame. Combined with a lack of any reliable recovery, this gives Mesprit extreme longevity issues, particularly Choice Scarf sets, which will rarely outspeed any other boosted Pokemon. Furthermore, Mesprit's special coverage can be lacking at times, as Mesprit can struggle against Steel-types such as Silvally-Steel and Togedemaru. Ultimately Mesprit's role compression can be very useful for covering weaknesses, but Mesprit will never be the best at any one role it attempts to cover.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Choice Scarf lets Mesprit revenge kill Pokemon such as Sneasel and +1 Dragon Dance Scrafty. Many different teammates appreciate Healing Wish support from Mesprit, from recovery-lacking wallbreakers like Magmortar to sweepers looking to set up twice such as Dragon Dance Scrafty. However, Trick can be run in this slot instead to cripple bulky Pokemon that otherwise wall Mesprit such as Jellicent and check bulky setup sweepers such as Cosmic Power Claydol. Mesprit rarely has opportunities to guarantee a safe switch in and needs to be brought in when a teammate has been KOed, via good predictions, or using pivoting. Slow pivots such as Silvally-Fairy and Lanturn are great options to safely bring Mesprit in and form a VoltTurn core. This will ideally be supplemented with a strong wallbreaker such as Sneasel or Trevenant ready to be brought in on a convenient pivot to do some damage.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description: Nasty Plot turns Mesprit into a fairly powerful wallbreaker, being able to 2HKO most of the tier after a single boost. The last moveslot is fairly customizable; Shadow Ball is Mesprit's best move for Steel-types like Togedemaru and Galarian Stunfisk, but Thunderbolt is an effective way to threaten Flying- and Water-types like Charizard and Jellicent before Mesprit sets up. Colbur Berry is the preferred item, as it makes Mesprit harder to revenge kill with Dark-types like Sneasel and Absol and fare better versus Choice Scarf Passimian's Knock Off. Life Orb is a more powerful item that might even remove the need for Mesprit to set up, but the lack of longevity is such that Mesprit is unlikely to have many chances to wallbreak. A Timid nature allows Mesprit to outspeed Modest Magmortar and Jolly Tsareena among other threats, but Modest can be run for more damage output. Passimian is a good partner because it can use U-turn to bring Mesprit in for easy setup opportunities on Pokemon such as Weezing and is a capable check to the Steel-types that give Mesprit issues. Due to Mesprit's lack of longevity, it often pairs well with a secondary wallbreaker like Magmortar or Archeops to keep up offensive pressure after Mesprit has been KOed. Sweepers and cleaners such as Ribombee and Lycanroc can make good use of Mesprit's wallbreaking to clean up the opposing team.

sets.name: Offensive Stealth Rock
sets.description: Mesprit's final moveslot is largely dependent on how badly you want Healing Wish on your team. U-turn is far more useful for keeping up momentum and preventing Mesprit from becoming too predictable, but Healing Wish can be an effective way to supplement setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Charizard. Mesprit's best qualities are its good speed for a Stealth Rock setter and favorable matchup against several entry hazard removers such as Golbat and Hitmontop. Despite this set's lack of defensive investment, having few weaknesses means it often has the time to set up Stealth Rock and fire off multiple attacks. Few weaknesses and access to U-turn allow Mesprit to keep up momentum in a way few Stealth Rock users can, making it an ideal pick for more offensive teams. Its inability to deal much damage to special walls or Steel-types means that wallbreakers such as Trevenant and Charizard make for good partners. Mesprit appreciates Pokemon that can punish U-turn, such as Rocky Helmet Druddigon and Coalossal, which can discourage Pokemon like Passimian and Togedemaru from freely pivoting versus Mesprit. Mesprit can also opt for a more defensively oriented spread that runs both U-turn and Healing Wish while foregoing Dazzling Gleam. However this set runs into extreme competition from Uxie, which is both faster and bulkier than Mesprit at the cost of being mildly less threatening due to its lower offenses and inability to bluff more threatening sets.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Shadow Ball is Mesprit's best way to hit Steel- and Psychic-types, U-turn eases Mesprit's reliance on predictions while gaining momentum in the process, and Trick can cripple switch-ins such as Articuno and Galarian Stunfisk. Choice Specs Mesprit is extremely prediction reliant, so having at least one of U-turn and Trick can be vital for a safer option that does not leave Mesprit Choice locked into an exploitable attack. Even with Dazzling Gleam, Dark-types greatly hinder Mesprit's ability to freely spam Psychic, so a solid Dark-type answer such as Passimian or Aromatisse is important. Mesprit is not the strongest wallbreaker around, so entry hazard setters such as Froslass and Regirock are advised to supplement its damage output. Weaker or non-boosting cleaners such as Dragon Dance Charizard and Tsareena are ideal Pokemon to make use of Mesprit's wallbreaking. Mesprit will also require a solid defensive core with blanket checks such as Palossand, Jellicent, and Weezing ready to cover the wide variety of threats capable of revenge killing Mesprit after minimal chip damage.

Gigalith.overview: Gigalith’s excellent natural bulk in tandem with Sand Stream allows it to act as one of PU’s most wisely useful Pokemon. Its typing allows it to resist common threats such as Galarian Articuno, Scyther, and Charizard, and, with base 135 attack it is by no means passive. However, Gigalith has no means of recovery outside of Leftovers and is prone to being worn down. Its pure Rock typing can be a detriment at times, as Pokemon such as Hitmontop and Tsareena can come in on it for free and proceed to remove Gigalith’s hazards while threatening it out with their STAB moves.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Stone Edge can be run over Rock Blast for more immediate damage, but its low PP and accuracy make it unreliable at times. Earthquake hits Pokemon such as Coalossal and Aggron for good damage, improving Gigalith’s matchup against the two. Protect is used to scout for Choice-locked Pokemon such as Passimian and Togedemaru, as well as to gain additional Leftovers recovery and rack up residual Sandstorm damage. Toxic can be run to cripple Pokemon such as Whimsicott and punish safe switch-ins such as Regirock and Palossand, which would otherwise come in on it for free. Gigalith should be paired with team members that can deal with Water-, Grass-, or Fighting-types, such as Lanturn, Ferroseed, and Weezing. Lanturn is also able to support Gigalith with Heal Bell, allowing it to better check Pokemon like Charizard that commonly run Toxic, while Ferroseed can cripple switchins like Charizard with Knock Off while giving Gigalith switchin opportunities. Other teammates such as Scyther and Whimsicott appreciate Gigalith’s ability to handle Fire- and Flying-types, and Whimsicott also deals with the Water- and Ground-types that give Gigalith trouble.

sets.name: SubSalac
sets.description:
Swoobat finds a niche in PU as a late-game sweeper, utilizing its ability in Simple and access to Substitute to acquire boosts from Calm Mind and Salac Berry to empower its Stored Power. Substitute provides Swoobat with an opportunity to set up multiple Calm Minds, letting it avoid status such as Toxic from Klinklang and helping it activate its Salac Berry. Stored Power utilizes the boosts from Calm Mind and Salac Berry and allows Swoobat to break through specially defensive walls such as Type: Null, Lickilicky, and Unaware Pyukumuku. Heat Wave serves as coverage for Steel- and Dark-types such as Klinklang, Mawile, and Pawniard. Alternatively, Roost provides Swoobat with recovery, letting it set up multiple Substitutes. Nasty Plot is a notable mention over Calm Mind, providing Swoobat with immediate wallbreaking power at the cost of not improving its special bulk, giving it worse matchups against threats like Shadow Ball Beheeyem and Calm Mind Drifblim. Thanks to Simple, Salac Berry provides Swoobat with a +2 boost to Speed, helping it outspeed offensive checks such as Choice Scarf Manectric and Golduck. As an alternative, Kee Berry boosts Swoobat's Defense, making it harder to revenge kill with priority moves like Pawniard's Sucker Punch and Falinks's First Impression.
