Swoobat is mainly found on offensive teams that can weaken its checks and enable it to set up and sweep. Pairing Swoobat with Fighting-types such as Throh, Falinks, and Hitmonchan is ideal, since they provide a check to Steel- and Dark-types like Klinklang and Pawniard, especially if Swoobat is not running Heat Wave. Furthermore, they can threaten specially defensive walls like Type: Null and Lickilicky, two foes that can pressure Swoobat with Shadow Claw and Knock Off, respectively. Swoobat is susceptible to priority Shadow Sneak from Gourgeist and Dusknoir, so answers to them like Unfezant and Morpeko make for good partners. Pivots such as Boltund, Golduck, and the aforementioned Morpeko can bring Swoobat safely into battle and provide it with more setup opportunities, with Morpeko also providing Parting Shot support. Memento support from Alolan Dugtrio is valuable, weakening a foe and letting Swoobat set up safely. Fellow special attackers like Lilligant and Glaceon can cripple and weaken shared checks like Klinklang and Type: Null, helping Swoobat clean late-game. Physically defensive walls like Stunfisk and Sandslash complement Swoobat by serving as checks to revenge killers like Choice Scarf Unfezant and Boltund while setting up entry hazards to wear down opposing foes; in return, they appreciate Swoobat setting up and threatening their checks like Appletun, Lilligant, and Golduck. The aforementioned Sandslash as well as Defog users such as Drifblim and Silvally-Rock can help remove Stealth Rock, keeping Swoobat healthy to enable more setup opportunities.

Sawk.overview: Among the myriad of Fighting-types in PU, Sawk tries to stand out thanks to its above average Speed tier that allows it to overcome certain threats of the tier such as Gallade, Mesprit, and Magmortar. Sawk also has very good coverage, its movepool including moves like Knock Off, Poison Jab, Stone Edge, and Earthquake which, coupled with its access to Mold Breaker allow it to defeat the most common switch-ins to other Fighting-types, such as Weezing, Charizard, and Whimsicott. Sawk is very frail though, but this problem can be handled thanks to its ability Sturdy, allowing it to survive a hit from full HP and retaliate, making it a dangerous threat to offensive archetypes. However, it has no real defensive utility, and nothing in his movepool pushes it over the edge, so Fighting-types such as Gallade and Passimian are often preferred over it.

sets.name: Choice Attacker
sets.description: This set makes switching into Sawk's Close Combat a really difficult task that only a few pokemon such as Aromatisse, Uxie, and Weezing can afford to accomplish. But Sawk's coverage makes up for that problem: Earthquake, paired with its ability Mold Breaker allows it to beat Weezing with Earthquake and eases prediction against Rotom, while Knock Off is good for getting rid of items, as well as hitting Psychic- and Ghost-types such as Mesprit, Uxie, and Gourgeist-S. Poison Jab rounds off the set, hitting Fairy-types such as Aromatisse and Ribombee super effectively. Sawk greatly appreciates teammates that are capable of bringing it in against Pokemon like Gigalith, Regirock, and Aggron with pivoting moves, such as Archeops, Togedemaru, and Scyther. Cleaners such as Ribombee really appreciate Sawk's ability to get rid of their counters such as Regirock, Gigalith, and Weezing, and Ribombee can also set up Sticky Web, making Sawk a lot harder to revenge kill. However, if Sticky Web is not set up, Sawk is super easy to revenge kill and needs a strong defensive core to back it up. Therefore, hazard setters like Weezing and Gigalith also make for good partners, improving Sawk’s wallbreaking potential.

sets.name: Sturdy Boots
sets.description: This set makes good use of Sawk's Sturdy ability and Heavy-Duty Boots keeping it intact. Knock Off is its main coverage option, allowing it to deal good damage to Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Jellicent, Mesprit, and Claydol. Knock Off can also make Sawk a lot harder to revenge kill by getting rid of Choice Scarf from Pokémon such as Mesprit and Passimian. Poison Jab hits Fairy-types such as Silvally-Fairy and Ribombee super effectively, and Earthquake deals good damage to Neutralizing Gas Weezing and Lanturn. This Sawk set works particularly well on offensive teams thanks to its ability to stop sweeps, as it is able to revenge kill a lot of threats such as Scrafty, Lycanroc, and Silvally-Steel. Cleaners such as Ribombee and Silvally-Ghost really appreciate Sawk's ability to wear down their checks such as Golbat, Sandaconda, and Weezing.

Whimsicott.overview: Whimsicott is a very versatile Pokemon; its good offensive Fairy typing and immaculate Speed tier let it revenge kill Pokemon such as Heliolisk and Swords Dance Gallade, and it has a defensive presence with its great typing, Prankster, and ability to annoy opposing Pokemon with status moves. It is difficult to play around due to the unpredictability that comes with the great variety of sets it can run and its Speed. However, Whimsicott lacks the Special Attack and coverage to deal much damage; it notably struggles to beat Alolan Exeggutor without a Choice Specs despite being a Fairy-type. This make it rely on utility and status moves to disrupt foes. It also lacks great defensive stats to constantly check threats such as Regirock.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description: U-turn is used to get Whimsicott out of bad matchups, especially after using Switcheroo, when its power is lower. It is especially useful against Silvally-Steel, which walls this set and is not affected by Switcheroo. Psychic hits Poison-types very hard, doing massive amounts of damage to Garbodor and Weezing, while being a reliable way to hit Fire-types neutrally. Hurricane hits Fire-types harder, 2HKOing Centiskorch and usually 2HKOing offensive Charizard, but is much less reliable than Psychic. Switcheroo is used to disrupt defensive cores, as Whimsicott can force in a Pokemon such as Charizard or Togedemaru that would otherwise wall it and limit the Pokemon's counterplay by giving it Choice Specs. Pixie Plate is an alternative to Choice Specs that sacrifices strength for flexibility, making prediction less of a factor. Whimsicott offensively pairs well with Pokemon that break Fire- and Steel-types, most notably Fighting-type Pokemon that can run Rock-type coverage such as Passimian and Sawk. Defensively, it appreciates support from Steel-types such as Silvally-Steel and Togedemaru to switch into Poison-, Flying-, and Ice-type moves, as well as a bulky Water-types such as Jellicent and Lanturn to handle Fire- and Steel-types. With U-turn, Whimsicott can form a solid VoltTurn core with the latter partner.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: Knock Off allows Whimsicott to remove important items such as Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots from defensive Pokemon such as Aromatisse and Charizard, making them much less effective at checking offensive threats, while Prankster Encore deals with offensive Pokemon such as Toxicroak by locking them into a setup move. U-turn is a crucial move for this set, allowing Whimsicott to let wallbreakers such as Lycanroc and Passimian in on its answers like Charizard and Togedemaru. Stun Spore provides speed control against fast Pokemon such as Ribombee on the switch so that Pokemon such as Scrafty can sweep much more easily. Leech Seed gives Whimsicott a form of recovery, allowing it to exploit defensive Pokemon to increase its longevity. Whimsicott pairs very well with Pokemon that like its usual Steel-, Fire-, and Flying-type switch-ins crippled, such as Frosmoth and Scyther.

sets.name: SubSeed
sets.description: This set uses Prankster to its fullest potential, catching opposing Pokemon with a Leech Seed and then using Substitute before they can act. The combination of Leftovers and Leech Seed recovery almost makes up for the HP loss of using Substitute every turn, slowly draining the opposing Pokemon's HP until it's in range of a Moonblast. Psychic can be used to annoy Poison-types that can easily break your Substitute, while Knock Off is used to disrupt defensive Pokemon with recovery that can stall Leech Seed. Encore can be used to prevent setup Pokemon such as Ribombee from taking advantage of this set's passive nature while also stalling out the recovery of defensive Pokemon such as Palossand. This set struggles most against Grass-types such as Tangela and Tsareena, and Whimsicott must be wary of moves such as Dual Wingbeat from Archeops and Scyther that both break its Substitute and damage it. Defensively, Whimsicott needs Pokemon such as Silvally-Steel and Stunfisk-Galar that can tank hits from Pokemon that can get past its Substitute, and these teammates can also benefit from the passive recovery that Leech Seed gives them. It also benefits from Flying- and Fire-types such as Charizard and Magmortar that deal with the Grass-types it struggles against.

Basculin.overview: Utilizing Adaptability and its good Speed tier, Basculin is a good offensive threat in the metagame, being able to function as both a strong physical and special wallbreaker and outspeeds common offensive threats such as the Silvally formes. Unfortunately, the tier is full of common Water immunities such as Toxicroak and Heliolisk, which prevent Basculin from spamming its STAB moves frequently; outside of using its STAB moves, Basculin lacks in damage output. While it takes a bit of support to use, once the Water immunities are dealt with, Basculin can use its high damage output to wallbreak efficiently.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: Superpower is Basculin's preferred coverage option in order to deal with certain Water-resistant and Water-immune Pokemon like Heliolisk and Guzzlord. Psychic Fangs is used to hit Toxicroak and Qwilfish, two Pokemon that otherwise wall Basculin, but Aqua Jet can instead be used to revenge kill faster threats such as Archeops. Ice Beam is another alternative to hit opposing Grass-types like Tangela and Alolan Exeggutor. Basculin appreciates partners that are able to deal with Jellicent, which shuts down Basculin. Heliolisk is a great example, and it appreciates Basculin's ability to deal with special walls like Gigalith and Assault Vest Guzzlord. Basculin also struggles with Pokemon like Toxicroak and Tangela depending on what coverage move it opts to use, so teammates like Charizard and Garbodor are greatly appreciated. Basculin welcomes entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ferroseed and Mesprit, which enables it to increase its wallbreaking capabilities. Mesprit, in addition to the aforementioned Heliolisk, can also form a VoltTurn core with Basculin, giving Basculin additional opportunities to come onto the field safely. Mesprit in particular also offers Healing Wish support to increase Basculin's longevity.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Ice Beam is Basculin's best coverage option, allowing it to hit opposing Dragon- and Grass-type Pokemon such as Silvally-Dragon and Tsareena, as well as certain Water-immune Pokemon like Toxicroak and Heliolisk for good damage. Flip Turn lets Basculin get free damage on its incoming switch-ins like Lanturn while maintaining offensive momentum, which helps its teammates. Toxic is essential to cripple Jellicent and Lanturn. However, locking into Toxic has its drawbacks of forcing Basculin out versus Steel- and Poison-types like Togedemaru and Toxicroak. Defensive partners like Assault Vest Guzzlord are nice to handle the strong Electric-types in the tier like Heliolisk and Rotom, and it punishes incoming switch-ins with Knock Off chip damage, which is vital for Basculin to secure KOs.

Scrafty.overview: Scrafty can be run as an either bulky or fast setup sweeper, sporting both Bulk Up and Dragon Dance. Its solid bulk and defensive typing give it various opportunities to switch in against and set up on Pokemon such as Weezing and Palossand. However, this same typing also gives it weaknesses to common types such as Fairy and Fighting, which are often run as coverage on Pokemon Scrafty wants to check such as Mesprit and Absol. Scrafty's typing also has its ups and downs offensively, as it is able to hit most of the tier neutrally, but Fairy-types such as Aromatisse and Silvally-Fairy completely wall it if it is not running coverage. While Scrafty's defenses are good, its Attack is underwhelming without boosts and its Speed is very mediocre, with it still being outsped even at +1 by Pokemon such as Ribombee and Whimsicott.

sets.name: Bulk Up
sets.description: This set allows Scrafty to serve as a special sponge that can soft check special attackers such as Rotom, which it can use as setup fodder. This pairs well with Bulk Up because, after setting up, Scrafty can take both physical and special hits, ideally allowing it to slowly break through the opponent's remaining Pokemon. This is furthered by its combination of Rest and Shed Skin, which makes Scrafty harder to wear down and cripple with status conditions, although Shed Skin can be unreliable at times. Drain Punch also helps keep Scrafty healthy, while Knock Off does decent damage while crippling Pokemon that may depend on their items such as Ribombee and Choice Scarf Passimian. Scrafty prefers to start setting up after threats to it such as Passimian and Aromatisse have been taken out, so Pokemon that can help against those such as Uxie, Togedemaru, and Rotom make for good teammates.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description: Dragon Dance gives Scrafty a greater offensive presence, with Moxie giving it an easier time sweeping and maximum Speed with a Jolly nature allowing it to outspeed base 110 Speed Pokemon after one Dragon Dance. Close Combat serves as its powerful STAB move, although High Jump Kick is slightly more powerful and has no defense drops in exchange for considerably more risk. Iron Head hits Fairy-types like Silvally-Fairy and Aromatisse. Lum Berry gives Scrafty one-time protection from status conditions that would otherwise make it much harder to sweep, but Chople Berry can instead be used to take moves such as Close Combat from Choice Scarf Passimian, which still outspeeds +1 Scrafty, and Hitmontop's Mach Punch. Shed Skin can be run if using a Chople Berry so Scrafty can still set up against status inflicting Pokemon like Jellicent. Good teammates are Pokemon that can help against faster threats such as Ribombee and the previously mentioned Choice Scarf Passimian. Both Silvally-Fairy and Silvally-Steel make for good teammates, as they can check these threats and bring Scrafty onto the field with Parting Shot. Wallbreakers like Magmortar and Vikavolt can weaken bulky Pokemon such as Weezing and Aromatisse, making it easier for Scrafty to clean up the match.

Cofagrigus.overview: Cofagrigus sets itself apart from other Ghost-types through its useful supportive and defensive capabilities. Because of its access to Toxic Spikes, Cofagrigus can aid its teammates by wearing down their checks while doing the same to its own checks, such as Palossand and Jellicent. Its Ghost typing and bulk are useful for denying Rapid Spin from Pokemon such as Tsareena and Hitmontop, and Iron Defense + Body Press pressures Defoggers such as Silvally-Steel. This combination of moves is also useful late-game once Cofagrigus's checks have been worn down, making it a valuable asset throughout a game. However, Cofagrigus has a serious lack of reliable recovery and is forced to rely on Rest, rendering it setup fodder for Pokemon such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and Quiver Dance Ribombee. It also has lackluster Special Defense, which lets wallbreakers such as Vikavolt and Magmortar easily pierce through it.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Shadow Ball is an interesting alternative over Toxic Spikes to hit Ghost-types, which otherwise wall Cofagrigus. Notably, this includes Rotom, Heavy-Duty Boots Froslass, and opposing Cofagrigus, which are not heavily impacted by Toxic Spikes. However, the supportive capabilities of Toxic Spikes are generally preferred due to these Pokemon being uncommon, and Toxic Spikes is more useful during the early- and mid-game stages. Despite Chesto Berry usually being run to give Cofagrigus a one-time instant recovery option alongside Rest, running no item makes it harder to pressure with Poltergeist and Knock Off users such as Froslass, Gourgeist-S, and Passimian. The Speed investment lets it outspeed Galarian Stunfisk, and the remaining EVs combined with a Bold nature bolster Cofagrigus's physical bulk, which improves its durability and the damage output of Body Press. Alternatively, a specially defensive spread of 248 HP / 240 SpD / 20 Spe with a Calm nature allows it to take special hits better at the cost of its physical bulk and attacking power. Cofagrigus should be paired with Pokemon that can cover for it against special attackers; these include blanket special walls such as Gigalith and Lanturn. These examples also benefit from Toxic Spikes pressuring checks like Jellicent and Quagsire. Offensive partners such as Tsareena and Choice Scarf Togedemaru appreciate Cofagrigus's Toxic Spikes, and, in return, both can safely pivot into Cofagrigus. Tsareena can also remove entry hazards on its side and Heavy-Duty Boots from foes for Cofagrigus with Rapid Spin and Knock Off, respectively. Cofagrigus also appreciates Pokemon that can threaten grounded Poison-types, as they remove Toxic Spikes; this includes Charizard, Mesprit, and Sandaconda.

Archeops.overview: Archeops is a very threatening Pokemon in the PU tier thanks to its fantastic offensive stats, vivid movepool, and great Speed tier. Earthquake and Stone Edge give Archeops near-perfect coverage that leaves its switch-ins restricted to a marginal few, such as Claydol, Palossand, and Regirock. Archeops also has a decent defensive typing, allowing it to check foes like Scyther in a pinch; however, it is held back by its poor defensive stats. It doesn't want to be the sole defensive switch-in to any foe, preferring to pivot in on resisted attacks such as Centiskorch's Fire Lash. Defeatist is a dreadful ability that basically makes Archeops useless if it drops below 50%, further hindering its ability to hard switch into foes like Scyther well and making it very dependent on both Heavy-Duty Boots and Roost.

sets.name: Heavy-Duty Boots
sets.description: U-turn is the preferred option in the third slot to generate momentum against foes like Palossand. Dual Wingbeat is an option that lets you OHKO Sturdy Sawk and revenge kill other Grass- and Fighting-types, like Tsareena and Gallade, more reliably. Roost is necessary to offset HP loss that activates Defeatist. Heavy-Duty Boots is another important tool that prevents Archeops's Stealth Rock weakness from wearing it down into Defeatist range. Archeops fits best on offensive teams, and it should primarily be brought in via safe switches in to wallbreak or revenge kill threats such as Galarian Articuno and Magmortar, as its lack of defensive utility prevents it from getting many free turns otherwise. For this reason, partners with pivoting moves like Ribombee and Whimsicott work well with Archeops, and they form a pivot core if Archeops is using U-turn. Lanturn is another partner that can bring Archeops in safely, and it can absorb both Water- and Electric-type attacks aimed at Archeops as well as provide an additional check to Togedemaru. Froslass can help pressure many of Archeops's checks, like Palossand and Rhydon thanks to its access to Spikes, notably bringing walls like Jellicent into 2HKO range of Stone Edge. Pokemon like Sneasel and Choice Specs Ribombee are problematic foes for Archeops, as they are faster and threaten to KO it, so Silvally-Steel and Choice Scarf Passimian can help pressure them.

sets.name: Suicide Lead
sets.description: Archeops is a good Stealth Rock setter on hyper offense teams. Its high Speed tier lets it block opposing entry hazard setters with Taunt, and it can KO itself with Head Smash to bring a teammate in safely and prevent Rapid Spin and Defog from removing its hazards. Focus Sash ensures that it can almost always set Stealth Rock; however, once it is brought into Defeatist range, there isn't too much value in preserving Archeops. Archeops can pretty much support every offensive threat in the tier, and it should almost always be the lead on the hyper offense teams it is used on. Passimian is a fantastic partner alongside Archeops, as it is the best Defog deterrent on hyper offense teams thanks to Defiant. Nasty Plot Mesprit and Swords Dance Silvally-Fairy are other offensive threats that appreciate the support Archeops provides. Offensive checks to Sneasel such as Silvally-Steel are helpful because it can prevent Stealth Rock from being set with Triple Axel, assuming it lands two hits. Many of the aforementioned Pokemon can also bring Archeops in safely with U-turn to find opportunities to set Stealth Rock if it was unable to earlier on.

sets.name: Cosmic Power + Stored Power
sets.description:
Gothitelle faces competition from other Psychic-types like Musharna, Mr. Rime, and Beheeyem, with these Pokemon fitting onto multiple teams more easily. This is because of them being more potent offensively, more reliably checking Throh, having reliable recovery, and generating momentum in Beheeyem's case. In spite of this, Gothitelle can still function as a solid bulky setup sweeper due to its decent bulk with investment, Cosmic Power further augmenting its defenses, and Stored Power allowing it to make excellent use of the boosts it accrues. Teams lacking Dark-types can struggle with Gothitelle, since even specially bulky Pokemon and Psychic-resistant Pokemon, such as Dusclops, Type: Null, and Silvally-Psychic, take too much damage after enough boosts. Stored Power also bypasses Pyukumuku's Unaware, meaning Gothitelle can be a major threat to stall teams. Leftovers lessens the need to use Rest and provides Gothitelle with passive recovery, while Colbur Berry reduces the damage that it takes from Dark-type coverage against foes like Grapploct. Competitive exploits moves and abilities that drop Gothitelle's stats, like Defog and Intimidate, by boosting its Special Attack and making Stored Power stronger. Moves like Mean Look and Thunderbolt can be used over Sleep Talk to trap and set up on passive foes or hit Dark-types, respectively, though forgoing Sleep Talk leaves Gothitelle completely helpless while it's asleep. Weakness Policy allows Gothitelle to take advantage of super effective coverage like Knock Off from Throh and U-turn from non-Swords Dance Silvally formes. This is an especially viable option, since most opponents will go for super effective moves against Gothitelle given its bulk.

Gothitelle fits best on bulkier builds, since its defensive nature and relatively low Speed would cost more offensive teams too much momentum. Dark-types like Pawniard and Galarian Linoone completely wall Gothitelle if its only attacking move is Stored Power. Fighting-types like Hitmontop and Throh are important teammates to have because of this, with the former also removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin and the latter wearing teams down through the combination of Circle Throw and Knock Off. Strong attackers like Silvally-Bug, Choice Specs Glaceon, and Nasty Plot Raichu can overwhelm Gothitelle faster than it can boost, meaning that teammates to pressure these wallbreakers, like Lapras and Roselia, are appreciated. Roselia can also pressure opposing teams with Spikes and Toxic Spikes, making it easier for Gothitelle to sweep. Silvally formes like Silvally-Bug and Silvally-Electric can also be useful partners, providing support through blocking Trick and Switcheroo from Mr. Mime and Manectric, breaking through foes like Mawile, and potentially removing entry hazards with Defog. In return, Gothitelle can absorb status conditions and set up on potential revenge killers like Manectric locked into Overheat. Pairing Gothitelle with Dark-types, notably Taunt Pawniard, can prevent a potential stalemate against opposing bulky Stored Power users like Musharna and Duosion.

Jellicent.overview: Jellicent is one of the best defensive Water-types in the tier. Compared to its primary competitor in Lanturn, however, Jellicent brings to the table an excellent Ghost typing further enhanced by its myriad of supportive options such as Will-O-Wisp, Taunt, and Recover. Because of this, Jellicent is an effective switch-in to Fighting-types like Choice Scarf Passimian as well as an excellent defensive check to various physical attackers such as Kabutops and Silvally-Steel. Jellicent also provides teams additional utility by punishing Water-types or Choice-locked attackers depending on if it's running Water Absorb or Cursed Body. However, Jellicent can be rather passive due to its low offensive capabilities and reliance on status as the typical way of dealing damage. Furthermore, Jellicent struggles versus common special attackers such as Whimsicott and Galvantula, as many of them can comfortably switch in and typically are not overly bothered by Will-O-Wisp or Toxic.

sets.name: Defensive Utility
sets.description: Will-O-Wisp is the preferred status move as a way to catch many physical attackers that threaten Jellicent such as Tsareena, Absol, Togedemaru, and Arctozolt; however, Toxic can be used here in order to better cripple bulkier checks such as Lanturn and opposing Jellicent. Hex is preferred as the sole attacking move on this set because it pairs well with its status moves versus bulkier defensive answers such as Lanturn. Colbur Berry is the optimal item in order to weaken Knock Off from the likes of Passimian or Gallade, but Heavy-Duty Boots can be used in order to be immune to entry hazards. Jellicent can also opt to not use an item, allowing it to switch into Choice Band Froslass, at the cost of some defensive utility against other threats. Gigalith makes a fantastic partner for Jellicent, as not only is it a good check to special attackers like Haunter, but with Sand Stream and hazard support, the residual damage Jellicent can spread with Will-O-Wisp and Toxic can severely cripple offensive answers like Whimsicott and Vikavolt. Conversely, Gigalith appreciates Jellicent's ability to reliably provide a Fighting immunity versus Choice-locked attackers like Passimian. Silvally-Fairy is also a fine partner, since it acts as a Knock Off absorber if Jellicent isn't running Colbur Berry and handles Dark-types such as Absol. Whimsicott makes a great offensive partner for Jellicent thanks to its ability to offensively check Sandaconda, Scrafty, and Absol, whereas Jellicent can check Charizard decently well. 32 Speed EVs allow Jellicent to outspeed Carracosta and Taunt it, preventing it from setting up with Shell Smash.

Galvantula.overview: Due to its great Speed, good offensive typing and coverage, and ability to threaten common entry hazard removers like Charizard, Tsareena, and Golbat, Galvantula is an effective Sticky Web setter. Its access to Volt Switch in combination with these traits also makes it a decent pivot. However, Galvantula's meager Special Attack hinders its overall damage output. Opting for Life Orb does make up for this, particularly if Galvantula runs Thunder, but doing so means forgoing Heavy-Duty Boots and limiting its staying power. Galvantula also faces competition from other Sticky Web setters in Ribombee and Vikavolt. The former is better against Pokemon like Whimsicott due to its higher Speed, while the latter is much stronger, has Levitate and better bulk, and possesses similar coverage.

sets.name: Offensive Support
sets.description: Thunder is Galvantula's strongest STAB move and doesn't force it to switch out like Volt Switch does. The move's accuracy is also boosted by Compound Eyes, substantially increasing its reliability. Energy Ball can be used instead to put more pressure on Rock- and Ground-types like Regirock and Palossand. Heavy-Duty Boots negates the effects of entry hazards, giving Galvantula an easier time switching around and annoying offensive teams. Alternatively, Life Orb can be used to bolster Galvantula's offensive presence, giving it a high chance to OHKO Pokemon like defensive Mesprit with Bug Buzz after Stealth Rock. However, losing immunity to entry hazards and taking Life Orb recoil both decrease its overall longevity. Slower wallbreakers and setup sweepers like Haunter and Nasty Plot Rotom-F very much appreciate Galvantula both slowing down potential revenge killers, like Choice Scarf Passimian, with Sticky Web and generating momentum for them with Volt Switch. Both of these Pokemon also benefit from Galvantula's ability to force damage onto shared checks like Gigalith and Lanturn, and can break through bulkier walls like Galarian Stunfisk and Palossand in return. Rapid Spin users like Tsareena and Kabutops can give Galvantula's teammates easier entry without removing Sticky Web, maintain momentum with their respective pivoting moves, and offensively check Pokemon such as Palossand and Charizard. Support from the previously mentioned spinners can also allow Galvantula to more comfortably use Life Orb.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Choice Band Fraxure functions as one of PU's most dangerous wallbreakers and revenge killers due to its high Attack stat, access to First Impression, and powerful coverage options. First Impression revenge kills prominent threats like Galarian Mr. Mime, Mr. Rime, Silvally-Psychic, and Leafeon while also allowing Fraxure to get rid of weakened foes such as Silvally-Bug and Silvally-Ice. Poison Jab targets Shiinotic and Togetic, while Stomping Tantrum serves as coverage for Steel-types such as Mawile and Klang. Additionally, it allows Fraxure to weaken opposing walls such as Mareanie and Carkol without locking into Outrage. Maximum Attack and Speed investment with an Adamant nature bolsters Fraxure's offensive prowess while letting it outspeed Adamant Pawniard and offensive Mawile.

Choice Band Fraxure fits primarily on offensive builds that appreciate its ability to soften the opposing walls for its teammates. Fire- and Steel-types such as Heatmor, Mawile, and Pawniard complement Fraxure by serving as checks to Ice- and Fairy-types such as Glaceon, Shiinotic, and opposing Mawile. In return, Fraxure can take on Water- and Fire-types such as Mareanie, Palpitoad, and Carkol. Fighting- and Poison-types such as Throh, Hitmontop, and Roselia benefit from Fraxure's ability to remove Psychic-types with First Impression, providing them more opportunities to wallbreak, set up, or get up entry hazards. VoltTurn users such as Manectric, Raichu, and Silvally formes provide pivot support, allowing Fraxure to enter the battle safely against the likes of Carkol and Gloom and fire off a strong attack. Setup sweepers like Swords Dance Silvally formes, No Retreat Falinks, and Klang can take advantage of Fraxure pressuring mutual checks such as Mawile and Gourgeist-XL by setting up and sweeping late-game.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
The set highlights Fraxure's capability to utilize Dragon Dance to become a threatening setup sweeper. Furthermore, its typing allows it to have a good matchup against the premium Choice Scarf user in PU, Manectric. Scale Shot allows Fraxure to boost its speed even further to better outpace Choice Scarf users such as Golduck, although Outrage can still be used for more consistent high damage output. Stomping Tantrum threatens Steel-types such as Mawile, Pawniard, and Klang. Poison Jab serves as coverage for Fairy-types such as Shiinotic and Togetic. Eviolite bolsters Fraxure's defenses, letting it set up on opposing Pokemon such as Leafeon and Manectric. Alternatively, Lum Berry can be employed to provide an additional setup opportunity by serving as a one-time status removal tool against status such as burns from Mareanie and Carkol. A Jolly nature is preferred, allowing Fraxure to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame at +1, although Adamant can be utilized to provide additional power at the cost of not outspeeding Raichu and Persian at +1.

Dragon Dance Fraxure shines on offensive teams that can break down its checks, letting it function as a setup sweeper. Special attackers such as Beheeyem, Manectric, and Mr. Rime can enable Fraxure by weakening physical walls such as Mawile and Gourgeist-XL. Roselia is a notable partner for Fraxure due to it wearing down opposing threats with Spikes, serving as a check to Shiinotic, and absorbing Toxic Spikes, which can greatly jeopardize Fraxure's longevity if not running a Lum Berry. Furthermore, it can utilize Sleep Powder to provide more opportunities for Fraxure to set up. Healing Wish support from Mr. Rime and Galarian Mr. Mime allows Fraxure to get off attacks early-game and giving it multiple opportunities to set up and potentially sweep late-game. Revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Mr. Rime and Galarian Mr. Mime can threaten Fraxure; checks such as Klang and Lapras are appreciated.

Stunfisk-Galar.overview: Galarian Stunfisk's unique typing and great bulk make it a solid switch-in to attackers like Ribombee, Togedemaru, and Vikavolt, giving it a solid niche over other Ground- and Steel-types like Palossand and Silvally-Steel. It can also further support its team with Stealth Rock and other support moves like Yawn. However, while its typing is at times great, it can also be a hinderance when trying to switch into threats like Frosmoth and Lycanroc that Steel- and Ground-types, respectively, usually check. Its lack of reliable recovery also makes it quite easy to overwhelm.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description: Rock Slide allows Galarian Stunfisk to beat Bug- and Flying-types like Ribombee and Archeops more reliably, although Stone Edge can also be used to always knock Archeops into Defeatist range. Yawn prevents Pokemon like Tsareena and Palossand from freely switching into Galarian Stunfisk, while Pain Split gives it a mean of recovery, albeit unreliable. Aromatisse makes for a stellar partner thanks to ability to switch into threats like Scrafty for Galarian Stunfisk; it can also heal it back up with Wish, which it greatly appreciates. In return, Galarian Stunfisk checks Steel-types like Togedemaru and Silvally-Steel for Aromatisse. Similarly, Weezing and Silvally-Fairy can take on Fighting-types such as Passimian that it struggles against. Lastly, wallbreakers and setup sweepers like Trevenant and Quiver Dance Ribombee appreciate Galarian Stunfisk providing them with more opportunities to come in via Yawn.

Druddigon.overview: Druddigon makes an effective pivot with its Dragon typing and ability in Rough Skin, which is used in conjunction with Rocky Helmet to punish U-turn and Flip Turn users like Togedemaru and Basculin. Heavy Defense investment lets it switch into notable Pokemon such as Tsareena and Togedemaru. Druddigon also has a great supportive movepool with access to Stealth Rock and Glare. However, Druddigon is weak to common Fairy- and Ice-type attacks from Pokemon like Ribombee and Froslass, as well as lacking any reliable recovery options.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Dragon Tail can be used to phaze Pokemon and rack up damage with Stealth Rock against Defoggers such as Charizard or setup sweepers such as Cosmic Power Claydol. Otherwise, Dragon Claw makes a decent alternative. Glare is used to spread paralysis, mainly targeting Whimsicott and Ribombee that may try to switch into Druddigon. Earthquake provides good coverage with Dragon Tail, hitting Steel-types like Silvally-Steel and Togedemaru super effectively. Endure can be used as a way to accumulate an extra turn of Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin damage onto a foe, which can help check opposing Pokemon such as Triple Axel Froslass in a pinch. Leftovers can be used as an alternative to Rocky Helmet to provide Druddigon with more longevity. Silvally-Fairy and other fast wallbreakers pair well with Druddigon, as Druddigon can punish fast Pokemon like Togedemaru that attempt to revenge kill them. Silvally-Steel and Charizard help to cover Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Ribombee that attempt to take advantage of Druddigon. Togedemaru is another Fairy-resistant Pokemon that can provide Wish support, which helps Druddigon stay healthy throughout a game.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Meowstic-F finds a solid niche in PU as a frail, but fast, wallbreaker that threatens common Fighting-, Poison-, and Water-types. Thunderbolt devastates Water-types while serving as Meowstic-F's best method of hitting Dark- and Steel-types such as Pawniard, Thievul, Mawile, and Klang. Protect provides valuable utility, allowing Meowstic-F to block First Impression from Fraxure and Falinks while letting it scout for moves from Choice item users such as Manectric and Stonjourner and gain additional recovery if running Leftovers. Shadow Ball is a notable mention over Protect, allowing Meowstic-F to threaten opposing Psychic-types. Colbur Berry provides a one-time damage reduction against Dark-type moves, allowing Meowstic-F to potentially stay in against Pawniard and Thievul to retaliate with Thunderbolt while also reducing the damage from Throh's Knock Off and Falink's Throat Chop. Leftovers can be utilized over Colbur Berry to offer recovery, extending Meowstic-F's longevity. Competitive, in tandem with its naturally high Speed tier, allows Meowstic-F to outspeed and punish Defog from the various Silvally formes and other slower Defoggers such as Vibrava and Vespiquen.

Fighting-types such as Falinks, Throh, and Hitmontop appreciate Meowstic-F removing Poison-types such as Mareanie, Gloom, and Roselia that limit their effectiveness. In return, they are able to eliminate Dark- and Steel-types such as Pawniard, Thievul, and Klang that trouble Meowstic-F. Steel-types such as Mawile and Pawniard can help Meowstic-F by offering Stealth Rock support, wearing down opposing foes, and by serving as soft checks to Bug-types like Crustle and Silvally-Bug. Setup sweepers such as Klang, Eiscue, and Thievul can benefit from Meowstic-F removing Fighting-types, letting them set up and sweep late-game. Entry hazard setters such as Crustle and Roselia appreciate Meowstic-F's ability to punish Defog from Silvally formes to reliably get up their hazards, providing valuable residual damage that can make up for Meowstic-F's mediocre Special Attack stat.

Aromatisse.overview: Aromatisse is one of the best defensive Fairy-types in the tier, capable of checking powerful Fighting-types like Passimian and Scrafty. Aromatisse sets itself apart from its competition thanks to the Wish and Heal Bell support it can provide its teammates, as well as an immunity to Taunt and Encore. Unfortunately, Aromatisse's mono-Fairy typing, poor Special Attack stat and lack of coverage leave it prone to giving strong wallbreakers like Magmortar and Centiskorch and setup users like Silvally-Steel a free switch-in. Aromatisse is reliant on Wish to keep itself healthy, forcing it to use Protect very often, which can be a huge momentum drain. Aromatisse faces little direct competition but teams that do not need its Wish support may wish to invest in a Fighting-type check with more utility, such as Runerigus.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Heal Bell provides Aromatisse and its teammates with cleric support. Toxic allows Aromatisse to cripple Pokemon like Gigalith and Charizard. Calm Mind is an option for the last slot to give Aromatisse a more offensive precense; however, many Fairy-resistant Pokemon such as Centiskorch and Aggron can still overwhelm Aromatisse with sheer power. Aroma Veil is a useful ability that prevents Aromatisse from being shut down by Taunt and Encore. Heavy-Duty Boots is an alternative option over Leftovers to prevent Aromatisse from being worn down by entry hazards, though the passive recovery from Leftovers is generally preferred.

Aromatisse fits best on bulky offense and balance builds that value Wish support and a sturdy Fighting-type check. Silvally-Steel can give Aromatisse a safe switch-in against Fighting-types with Parting Shot or U-turn and provide Defog support to stop Aromatisse from being easily worn down by entry hazards. In return, Aromatisse can make up for Silvally-Steel's lack of recovery through Wish support. Weezing and Jellicent can help provide a secondary Fighting-type check, better handling Gunk Shot variants of Passimian, and can check offensive Steel-types like Aggron and Silvally-Steel, respectively. Gigalith and Lanturn can help check strong Fire-types such as Magmortar and Charizard that Aromatisse invites in, both also greatly valuing the Wish support Aromatisse provides.

Vikavolt.overview: Vikavolt is a wallbreaking powerhouse, sporting a massive base 145 Special Attack stat, powerful STAB attacks, Volt Switch, and decent coverage to boot. It can also switch into threats like Palossand and Passimian thanks to its passable bulk, typing, and access to recovery. However, Vikavolt is very slow for a wallbreaker, and its Bug typing can be a hindrance, as it leaves Vikavolt unable to switch into Pokemon like Regirock that it can otherwise easily pressure. It is often outclassed by Ribombee and Galvantula as a Sticky Web setter, as their Speed tier is much more suited for the aggressive playstyle, with Galvantula also sporting the same typing and Volt Switch. Similarly, Agility sets suffer from competition from Quiver Dance Ribombee.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: This set takes advantage of Vikavolt's wallbreaking potential, forcing out most Pokemon slower than it such as Sandaconda and Jellicent. Although Thunderbolt is a great reliable STAB move for Vikavolt, Sticky Web can be used on more offensive teams as speed control, giving Vikavolt a few more opportunities to outspeed and pressure opposing Pokemon such as Aggron and Adamant Absol but mostly serving to support its teammates. Bug Buzz is primarily used on Vikavolt as a reliable way to hit Pokemon that Electric-type moves cannot hit as well, such as Druddigon and Tsareena. However, Energy Ball is a useful alterative to hit Ground-types harder, such as Palossand and Rhydon, that may attempt to block Volt Switch. A good partner for this set is Passimian, which can assist in offensively checking common switch-ins such as Gigalith and Regirock and deter the opponent from using Defog thanks to Defiant. It can also form a solid VoltTurn core with Vikavolt. Other wallbreakers that appreciate the Sticky Web support like Magmortar and Silvally-Steel make for solid partners. The former appreciates Vikavolt taking on Water-types such as Lanturn, while the latter can pressure defensive behemoths like Gigalith for Vikavolt.

sets.name: Agility
sets.description: This set uses Vikavolt's wallbreaking potential and transforms it into a late-game sweeper, using Agility to make it faster than the entirety of the unboosted metagame. Vikavolt's natural bulk and typing let it use Agility against Choice Scarf Pokemon such as Passimian and Togedemaru as well as more defensive Pokemon that struggle to damage it such as Uxie and Claydol. Energy Ball is used to defeat Pokemon that resist its primary attacks, such as Palossand and Galarian Stunfisk. Roost, however, can give Vikavolt more longevity, allowing it to recover on more defensive threats to make it harder to revenge kill. This set pairs well with entry hazards setters such as Spikes Froslass and Qwilfish, as these help Vikavolt force its way past difficult-to-break Pokemon such as Gigalith and specially defensive Togedemaru. It also defensively pairs well with Ground-types such as Palossand and Sandaconda that resist Rock-type attacks from Pokemon such as Lycanroc and Regirock, since these Pokemon often stop Vikavolt from sweeping.

Ribombee.overview: Ribombee makes for an incredibly versatile threat due to its blistering Speed, good typing, and solid movepool. These traits render it capable of fulfilling multiple roles, ranging from an offensive pivot able to support its teammates with Sticky Web to a capable wallbreaker and cleaner with Choice Specs and Quiver Dance, respectively. It can also revenge kill various threats like Sneasel and Archeops. However, Ribombee struggles a lot against Steel- and Fire-types as well as specially defensive walls like Silvally-Steel, Magmortar, and Gigalith due to its average Special Attack and relative lack of coverage options.

sets.name: Quiver Dance
sets.description: Thanks to its decent coverage and great Speed, Ribombee makes for a fairly threatening setup sweeper. Roost allows Ribombee to use walls like non-Toxic Palossand as setup fodder and makes Ribombee a far more reliable answer to Scrafty. Bug Buzz hits Psychic- and Grass-types like Mesprit and Tsareena without needing a boost, while U-turn gives Ribombee more utility early- and mid-game when its checks are still healthy. Wallbreakers like Passimian and Trevenant are vital partners; they soften up Pokemon like Gigalith, Silvally-Steel, and Charizard, making Ribombee much more of a nuisance. Due to its poor bulk, teammates that can bring Ribombee in safely like Lanturn and Togedemaru make for stellar partners; the former can also switch into Fire-types such as Charizard. Lastly, other cleaners like Scrafty, Hitmonlee, and Silvally-Steel can set up on Ribombee's answers, and vice versa.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description: Ribombee's coverage and Speed make it a potent wallbreaker and revenge killer when wielding a Choice Specs. Sticky Web is an option over U-turn for Ribombee to support its teammates, while Switcheroo lets it cripple answers like Gigalith and Togedemaru. However, U-turn is the preferred option due to it easing prediction. Cleaners like Sneasel and Gourgeist-Small appreciate Ribombee weakening walls like Weezing and Silvally-Steel for them. Scrafty is another great teammate, as it can also take advantage of some of the various walls that Ribombee finds itself unable to break, such as specially defensive Togedemaru. Stealth Rock and other entry hazards are a huge nuisance to this particular set; they heavily dent Ribombee and make it easier to pick off with a priority move, meaning it has a harder time revenge killing Pokemon like Sneasel and Absol. This makes entry hazard control absolutely vital, with Charizard and Tsareena standing out as great options because they also deal with threats Ribombee struggles against.

sets.name: Offensive Support
sets.description: This set makes Ribombee a capable offensive pivot capable of supporting its teammates with Sticky Web. Stun Spore allows Ribombee to cripple threats it struggles against, like Charizard, while Psychic allows it to hit Poison-types, notably Weezing. U-turn takes advantage of the switches Ribombee forces and allows it to bring it teammates against the Pokemon it invites in. Pokemon like Passimian, Magmortar, and Silvally-Steel make for fantastic partners; not only do they greatly appreciate Ribombee's Sticky Web, but they can also easily take on threats Ribombee has a hard time against such as Togedemaru and Gigalith, with Passimian also deterring the opponent from removing Sticky Web with Defog. Due to Ribombee's unimpressive damage output, it appreciates Spikes from partners like Froslass, which can pressure Steel-types for Ribombee and also enjoys Ribombee being able to revenge kill or cripple faster threats like Sneasel. Froslass can also switch into Rapid Spin users like Hitmontop trying to get rid of Ribombee's Sticky Web.

Lycanroc.overview: Thanks to its amazing Speed, great Attack, and coverage, Lycanroc has established itself as a terrifying offensive threat capable of revenge killing multiple tier staples such as Charizard and Ribombee, which gives it an important niche over Archeops. While it does have a great Attack and movepool, it can struggle to get past physically defensive walls that aren't weak to its attacks like Tangela, Quagsire, and Sandaconda.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description: With this set, Lycanroc makes for a great revenge killer. Close Combat targets Pokemon like Gigalith, Togedemaru, and Regirock. If running Psychic Fangs, Lycanroc is going to find itself unable to break through Palossand and Claydol; partners that can take them on like Whimsicott and Tsareena are therefore appreciated. They can also weaken other walls such as Weezing in order for Lycanroc to clean. In exchange, they enjoy Lycanroc pressuring Pokemon like Charizard and Sneasel for them. If running Crunch, Lycanroc struggles against Fighting-types such as Hitmontop and Passimian, which makes teammates like Jellicent and Aromatisse appreciated. While Life Orb makes Lycanroc less prediction reliant, Choice Band makes it hit considerably harder while also not getting chipped down by Life Orb.

Tsareena.overview: Tsareena makes for a solid Rapid Spin user and wallbreaker thanks to its typing, great Attack, and solid movepool giving it a good matchup against common entry hazard setters and spinblockers like Gigalith and Jellicent, respectively. Moreover, its access to U-turn also allows it to maintain momentum for its team. However, its Speed tier and lackluster typing leave it vulnerable to many threats like Charizard, Rotom-F, and Silvally-Steel. Also, it is extremely vulnerable to status; it notably can't take advantage of common Water-types it threatens like Lanturn in fear of a Scald burn.

sets.name: Offensive Utility
sets.description: Knock Off cripples Pokemon like Druddigon, Charizard, and Togedemaru, while U-turn allows Tsareena to pivot out on its switch-ins. A Jolly nature makes Tsareena faster than attackers such as Adamant Absol and Modest Magmortar, but using an Adamant nature gives it more breaking power. Threats like Passimian, Rotom, and Mesprit appreciate Tsareena bringing them in against its answers like Silvally-Steel and Weezing; in return, they can form a momentum core with Tsareena, with the latter also providing Stealth Rock support. Lastly, Water-types such as Jellicent and Lanturn can check Fire- and Flying-types for Tsareena. The latter further supports Tsareena with Heal Bell and Volt Switch.

Passimian.overview: Passimian is a premier offensive pivot thanks to its wonderful coverage alongside access to U-turn. Furthermore, Passimian's impressive Attack and its resistance to Stealth Rock, which drastically increases its overall longevity, allow it to compete with other offensive pivots such as Togedemaru and Rotom. On top of this, Passimian's ability Defiant enables it to apply even more pressure versus teams when paired with entry hazard support. Aside from its average bulk, Passimian's main drawback is the predictability behind the set. Teams with Ghost-types or reliable Fighting-type answers with access to recovery are usually safe switch-ins to Passimian and could ultimately limit Passimian's ability to spam its STAB attacks.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Through the use of a Choice Scarf, Passimian outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame. In tandem with its naturally high Attack and the coverage to do so, this grants Passimian the offensive capability of revenge killing a majority of opposing offensive threats. Furthermore, Passimian tends to force switches thanks to its ability to check several offensive threats such as Silvally-Steel, Lycanroc, and Archeops. U-turn is essential for Passimian's role as a pivot, because Passimian can threaten common defensive Pokemon and force them out, such as Scrafty and Gigalith. Likewise, Knock Off can provide item disruption versus would-be switch-ins that would fear nothing from U-turn such as Ribombee. Rock Slide is the preferable fourth move for its ability to check Flying-types such as Charizard and Scyther. Gunk Shot is a good alternative to have a reliable way to punish Fairy-types such as Silvally-Fairy. Passimian often relies on prediction, as several teams carry solid Fighting checks, especially if facing Pokemon such as Jellicent and Palossand. Therefore, Choice Scarf Passimian partners incredibly well with Vikavolt or Regirock on entry hazard stacking teams that greatly appreciate a fast Pokemon and revenge killer and need methods of deterring Defog. Regirock is able to switch in comfortably versus Fighting-resists such as Charizard, whereas Vikavolt pressures bulky Water-types and can complete a VoltTurn core in order to bring Passimian in safely versus Pokemon such as Gigalith. On the other hand, Mesprit is able to handle defensive checks such as Weezing but also appreciates Passimian's ability to threaten the defensive behemoths that wall it such as Galarian Stunfisk and Lanturn.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Passimian's monstrous Attack alongside its expansive coverage grants it a fine role as a wallbreaker with pivoting capabilities in order to turn the tides versus defensive teams. Seed Bomb is ideal as Passimian's fourth move, as it provides devastating damage versus several common walls that resist or are immune to Close Combat such as Palossand, Jellicent, and Claydol. For perspective, Jellicent and Claydol are 2HKOed by it, whereas Palossand has a high chance to be 2HKOed after Stealth Rock. Earthquake is an option to hit Neutralizing Gas Weezing, while Gunk Shot handles Fairy-types like Aromatisse and provides a strong neutral attack versus Pokemon like Vikavolt on the switch. Because of Passimian's wallbreaking capabilities and phenomenal coverage, it can be hard to handle for defensive playstyles, especially when paired with other VoltTurn members. Choice Scarf Togedemaru is an excellent partner for its ability to check faster threats to Passimian such as Silvally-Fairy, Whimsicott, and Ribombee. Passimian is also able to reliably wallbreak versus Togedemaru's counters such as Galarian Stunfisk and Lanturn. Entry hazard setters like Sandaconda and Froslass are wonderful partners, with Passimian, as not only will residual damage make its Choice Band-boosted attacks that much more difficult to switch into, Sandaconda also brings Glare support versus faster Pokemon like Whimsicott and appreciates Passimian's ability to deter Defog thanks to Defiant.

Palossand.overview: Palossand is an important defensive centerpiece in PU thanks to its good typing, bulk, access to Stealth Rock, and ability to check otherwise dangerous Pokemon like Archeops, Lycanroc, and Passimian. It can be very difficult to take down over the course of a game thanks to Shore Up, an excellent reliable recovery move that is often boosted in potency by the common presence that is Gigalith's sand. Its solid STAB coverage and decent Special Attack also make it somewhat difficult to switch into, reducing its passivity. Palossand can struggle somewhat with threats that its typing would otherwise allow it to check, though, like Silvally-Steel because of Toxic and Vikavolt because of Energy Ball. It can also be a major momentum drain due to how passive it can be, especially against bulkier teams.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description: Palossand's great bulk makes it possible for it to come in on foes like Togedemaru, Gigalith, Sawk, and Regirock, giving it ample opportunities to set up Stealth Rock. Colbur Berry provides Palossand with a buffer against Knock Off from the Fighting-types it checks and can also let it check Choice Band Sneasel locked into Knock Off. Checks to strong special attackers like Whimsicott and Ribombee are recommended, since Palossand can't handle them at all. Silvally-Steel can perform this role while also providing Defog support, which is very helpful, as Palossand can easily be worn down by Spikes damage. Lanturn provides useful defensive synergy and can further support Palossand with Heal Bell. Other good partners include Togedemaru, which can act as a good Vikavolt check, and Scrafty, which checks annoyances like Jellicent. Both of these Pokemon appreciate Palossand's ability to check Fighting-types and set up Stealth Rock to wear down their switch-ins.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description:
Type: Null's great bulk, which is further bolstered by Eviolite, and access to U-turn make it an incredible pivot able to switch into some of the premier special threats in the tier, like Mr. Rime and Lilligant. U-turn allows Type: Null to pivot out of unfavorable matchups and, thanks to its low Speed, bring a teammate in safely. While Toxic allows Type: Null to cripple Pokemon that try to take advantage of it like Crustle, Stunfisk, and Gourgeist, Crush Claw provides Type: Null with a STAB move that makes it considerably less passive and allows it to beat threats it otherwise wouldn't beat, like Calm Mind Galarian Rapidash. Rest allows it to stay healthy throughout the game and act as a status absorber, while Sleep Talk prevents it from being overly passive when sleeping, although it can be unreliable. Shadow Claw is an option over Toxic or Sleep Talk, as it allows Type: Null to beat Substitute + Calm Mind Drifblim.

Answers to Fighting-types, like Drifblim, Qwilfish, and Gourgeist-XL are vital partners, as they can switch into threats like Throh and Falinks that Type: Null struggles against. Drifblim also gets rid of entry hazards, which Type: Null greatly appreciates due to its lack of passive recovery, while Qwilfish sets Spikes and Toxic Spikes. In exchange, Type: Null acts as a reliable switch-in to Pokemon they're threatened by, like Appletun, Beheeyem, and Mr. Rime. Knock Off absorbers, along with Pokemon that can switch into Trick and Switcheroo, are appreciated, since Type: Null needs its item to do its job reliably. Pokemon holding a Rocky Helmet, such as Stunfisk and Runigerus, make for great switch-ins to Knock Off users like Mawile; they can also switch into threats like Perrserker and Silvally-Rock that threaten Type: Null, while they appreciate the latter's ability to switch into Ice-, Grass-, and Water-types. Teammates holding a Choice item like Unfezant and Gourgeist also work, as they can switch into Pokemon with Trick and Switcheroo like Choice Scarf Mr. Mime and Manectric, while they can also revenge kill Pokemon that can overwhelm Type: Null, like Throh. Gourgeist, in particular, can also cripple Pokemon like Calm Mind Musharna and Cosmic Power Gothitelle that Type: Null struggles against with Trick. Strong physical attackers like Choice Band Gourgeist-XL can easily overwhelm Type: Null; this makes answers to these, such as itemless Appletun, great options. They all appreciate Type: Null dealing with special attackers such as Lilligant they struggle against, while they can aid Type: Null in checking Electric-types such as Boltund for Tangela and Manectric in Gourgeist-XL's case. Frailer or slower threats appreciate Type: Null bringing them in safely against Pokemon like Dusknoir, Klinklang, and Stunfisk via U-turn. Choice Band Morpeko, Flame Orb Throh, and Choice Specs Golduck are prime examples, with the former being able to deal with Substitute Calm Mind Drifblim. Lastly, clerics such as Vespiquen and Togetic are appreciated, as Type: Null's reliance on Rest means it can be taken advantage of as well as overwhelmed. They also check Fighting-types like Hitmonchan and appreciate Type: Null dealing with Ice-types like Glaceon.

Silvally-Dragon.overview: With its natural bulk and unique coverage, Silvally-Dragon is able to serve as a consistent setup sweeper. Its typing allows Silvally-Dragon to set up on Pokemon like Tsareena and choice-locked Togedemaru. However, it is unable to provide much defensive utility throughout a match without jeopardizing its ability to sweep. Silvally-Dragon also ends up competing with Silvally-Steel, -Ghost, and -Fairy as a setup sweeper, as these types typically provide more defensive utility and find easier setup opportunities.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Silvally-Dragon is able to muscle through most foes with its STAB Multi-Attack. Iron Head nails Fairy-types like Aromatisse and Whimsicott. Flame Charge allows Silvally-Dragon to hit Steel-types such as Togedemaru and Silvally-Steel harder and outspeed Ribombee, Archeops, and Choice Scarf users like Passimian and Mesprit. With its offensive nature, Silvally-Dragon finds itself most commonly on Spikes stacking or dual screens offense teams. Silvally-Dragon struggles to get past physically defensive Pokemon like Regirock and Weezing, even after a boost, so it benefits from other wallbreakers like Nasty Plot Mesprit and Quiver Dance Ribombee. Healing Wish support from Mesprit lets Silvally-Dragon be more aggressive and wear down Weezing and Sandaconda without being too bothered by chip damage and potential status. Steel-types like Togedemaru and Aggron deal with opposing Fairy-types, and in return, Silvally-Dragon is able to break past Pokemon like Lanturn and Magmortar.

Silvally-Fairy.overview: Silvally-Fairy is a very versatile threat in the PU metagame thanks to a myriad of factors. Solid base 95 stats across the board and a wide movepool allow it to be easily constructed to fit a specific team's needs. With access to Defog, Parting Shot, and Thunder Wave, it can be a great support Pokemon, while access to Swords Dance and super effective coverage to hit common Fairy-type checks such as Togedemaru and Charizard let it be a great offensive Pokemon. A pure Fairy typing means it's great for checking and setting up on Dark- and Fighting-types such as Absol and Passimian. Silvally-Fairy's biggest flaw is its lack of any form of recovery. It is also susceptible to all entry hazards and status afflictions, making it easy to wear down and unable to check what it needs to consistently. Finally, it cannot fit all of what it wants on one set, limiting its options.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description: Parting Shot allows Silvally-Fairy to pivot out on would-be threats such as Togedemaru and Aggron. If Defog is unneeded, then Silvally-Fairy can run a status move of its choice to cripple an opposing Pokemon. Despite the Jolly nature, Flamethrower is chosen to hit Steel-types, hitting them harder than Fire Fang. The Speed investment allows Silvally-Fairy to outspeed Timid Magmortar, in addition to slower Pokemon like Absol and Shiftry, and the rest is invested into physical bulk. Notably, it lives a +1 Life Orb Iron Head from Dragon Dance Scrafty with two layers of Spikes up. Silvally-Fairy pairs best with Steel-types, building a solid defensive core with them. Togedemaru is a great option, as it can sponge Poison- and Steel-type attacks while healing Silvally-Fairy with Wish, and, in return, Silvally-Fairy can tank Fighting-type attacks for it. Psychic- and Dark-type attackers such as Mesprit and Scrafty heavily appreciate the absence of Dark- and Fighting-type checks as well as the Parting Shot support, making it easier for them set up without fear of being punished.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: A strong STAB move, great coverage, and two boosting moves let Silvally-Fairy tear through teams. Flame Charge is not only useful for hitting Steel-types, but it lets Silvally-Fairy boost its Speed, making it harder to revenge kill by Choice Scarf users such as Mesprit and Passimian. Rock Slide allows it to OHKO Charizard, while Psychic Fangs is a niche alternative that can take out a weakened Weezing. U-turn is also an option if Silvally-Fairy finds itself in a bad situation, however this means forgoing important coverage. Swords Dance Silvally-Fairy can be used as both a sweeper and a breaker, but be aware that it struggles to break past bulky physically defensive Pokemon such as Regirock and Aggron. Wallbreakers such as Shiftry and Basculin take advantage of these due to their super effective STAB moves while also weakening Fire- and Poison-types, making them solid partners for Silvally-Fairy. Cleaners such as Sneasel and Passimian also appreciate walls such as Regirock and Palossand being weakened so they can efficiently sweep.

Silvally-Ghost.overview: With access to boosting moves in Swords Dance and Flame Charge alongside a good offensive typing and strong stats, Silvally-Ghost makes for a strong setup sweeper. However, it faces stiff competition from the likes of Silvally-Fairy, which offers teams a stronger defensive typing with a plethora of useful resistances for a setup sweeper whilst maintaining the same coverage, meaning it's much more versatile and can fit on a wider variety of teams. Likewise, it also struggles to compare to other Ghost-types in the tier, such as Palossand and Jellicent, which provide teams excellent defensive support thanks to their solid secondary typing with useful immunities and supportive movepool.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Explosion is outstanding for its ability to provide a one-time nuke versus defensive checks such as Miltank and Scrafty. However, U-turn can be used as a way to gain momentum against the aforementioned Ghost-resists without sacrificing Silvally-Ghost's life in the process. Substitute allows Silvally-Ghost to avoid status from the likes of Lanturn and is a strong option against Sucker Punch users like Absol, but leaves Silvally-Ghost with no way to threaten other bulky Pokemon like Scrafty and Quagsire. Ribombee makes a great partner thanks to its ability to not only offensively check Dark-types like the aforementioned Scrafty, but it also provides Sticky Web support. Additionally, Silvally-Ghost can act as a spinblocker against the likes of Tsareena and Claydol and use either of them as setup fodder. Passimian makes a good offensive partner not only for its ability to check common Ghost-immune Pokemon such as Miltank, but it can pressure defensive checks to Silvally-Ghost like Scrafty and Regirock especially when safely brought in with U-turn.

Silvally-Ground.overview: Silvally-Ground is a strong setup sweeper thanks to its solid bulk, coverage, and offensive typing. This allows it to set up easily, as it can take neutral hits well and exploit Pokemon like Choice Scarf Togedemaru. However, it still has to compete with the other Silvally formes. Silvally-Fairy, -Steel, and -Ghost are often easier to fit onto teams with their defensive utility. Silvally-Ghost and Silvally-Water can also be more menacing offensively.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Silvally-Ground is able to maximize its sweeping potential with Rock Slide's coverage in combination with its STAB Multi-Attack and Speed boosts from Flame Charge. Rock Slide hits Flying-types such as Charizard and Archeops and does more damage to Bug-types like Ribombee and Scyther than Flame Charge. Silvally-Ground is most comfortable with a defensive backbone that takes advantage of its typing, fitting best on bulky offense teams with Spikes support to better facilitate a sweep; this makes Froslass and Alolan Sandslash valuable partners. In return, Silvally-Ground can check Pokemon like Lycanroc and Magmortar that normally muscle past them. Silvally-Ground can hardly do anything to Weezing and thus appreciates other wallbreakers like Charizard and Mesprit to remove it. Choice Scarf Mesprit makes for a good partner, as it can punish Weezing and provide Healing Wish support should Silvally-Ground take a Toxic from Regirock or Glare from Sandaconda while setting up. Healing Wish support also allows Silvally-Ground to be more easily used defensively early-game, not minding damage from Druddigon's Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin or chip from Togedemaru's U-turn. Mesprit appreciates Silvally-Ground checking Steel-types like Togedemaru and Aggron effortlessly in exchange. Silvally-Ground is able to also run a mixed Work Up set with Multi-Attack and BoltBeam coverage to cover the entire tier, most notably hitting Weezing significantly harder. However, it lacks the raw power behind Swords Dance and is harder to pull off an entire sweep with.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Silvally-Rock finds a solid niche in PU as a Swords Dance sweeper, obtaining setup opportunities against common foes such as Mr. Rime and Unfezant. Swords Dance bolsters Silvally-Rock's attacking prowess, letting it break through slower foes such as Appletun and Dusknoir. U-turn provides valuable utility and allows Silvally-Rock to pivot away from checks such as Sandslash and Throh. Alternatively, Flame Charge turns Silvally-Rock into a better late-game cleaner, boosting its Speed stat, letting it hit Klinklang, and enabling it to outspeed offensive checks such as Galarian Rapidash and Alolan Dugtrio and Choice Scarf users such as Drednaw and Golduck. Ice Beam serves as coverage for Ground-types such as Stunfisk and Sandslash. Psychic Fangs is a notable mention that allows Silvally-Rock to better break through Fighting-types like Throh and Falinks.

Swords Dance Silvally-Rock is often found on offensive builds that appreciate its ability to fire off strong Multi-Attacks, keep offensive momentum with U-turn, and potentially clean late-game. If running Flame Charge over U-turn, Silvally-Rock should be preserved until late-game when its checks have been weakened or removed and it can set up and sweep. Partners such as Unfezant and Morpeko weaken physical walls such as Stunfisk and Sandslash, helping facilitate a late-game sweep. Pairing Silvally-Rock with special wallbreakers such as Appletun, Nasty Plot Gourgeist, and Mr. Rime can be beneficial, as they can take advantage of the aforementioned physical walls and defensive Throh; Eject Pack Appletun can also provide more setup opportunities by bringing Silvally-Rock in on special walls such as Type: Null and Lickilicky. Stunfisk and Sandslash also make for good partners, providing checks to Steel-types such as Klinklang and Mawile and setting up entry hazards. Checks to Fighting-types such as Galarian Rapidash, Mr. Rime, and Unfezant are also appreciated, with the former two also providing Healing Wish support.

sets.name: Offensive Defog
sets.description:
Silvally-Rock finds a slight niche in PU as an offensive Defog user, thanks to its strong Multi-Attack that gives it good matchups against common foes such as Mr. Rime, Unfezant, and Drifblim. Ice Beam targets Ground-types such as Stunfisk and Sandslash, while Flamethrower punishes switch-ins from Steel-types such as Klinklang and Mawile, letting Silvally-Rock utilize Defog against Mawile. U-turn establishes offensive momentum, allowing Silvally-Rock to pivot away from and accrue residual damage on checks such as Sandslash and Throh.

This Silvally-Rock set fits on balance and bulky offense builds that appreciate its offensive capabilities and good utility in Defog and U-turn. Grass-types such as Appletun, Gourgeist, and Lilligant appreciate Silvally-Rock checking Fire- and Ice-types such as Flareon and Mr. Rime, as well as Flying-types like Unfezant and Drifblim. In return, they can threaten Water- and Ground-types such as Golduck, Stunfisk, and Sandslash. Lilligant is a notable partner, able to capitalize on switches that Silvally-Rock forces to set up with Quiver Dance or heal up Silvally-Rock with Healing Wish, depending on its set. Setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Galarian Rapidash and Calm Mind Musharna benefit from Silvally-Rock clearing entry hazards and improving their longevity; in return, they can remove Fighting-types such as Throh and Falinks that trouble Silvally-Rock. Wallbreakers such as Mr. Rime and Beheeyem appreciate Silvally-Rock luring in physical walls such as Stunfisk and Sandslash to wreak havoc. Pokemon such as Klinklang and Drifblim can also lure in the aformentioned physical walls and cripple them with Toxic, allowing Silvally-Rock to potentially get off a Defog against them.

Silvally-Steel.overview: Silvally-Steel is one of the best Steel-types PU has to offer. Its typing, alongside its respectable defensive stats, allow it to check prominent threats such as Sneasel, Whimsicott, and Ribombee. Silvally-Steel provides a lot of utility to teams through using momentum-gaining moves like Parting Shot and U-turn as well as being a great user of Defog. It can also take on a more offensive role with Swords Dance to break through its natural checks like Lanturn and Palossand. Unfortunately, it is held back by its lack of recovery, which leaves it easily worn down by entry hazards and strong attacks from Pokemon like Silvally-Fairy and Mesprit. It also struggles against many prominent attackers such as Passimian and Magmortar.

sets.name: Defensive Pivot
sets.description: Flamethrower allows Silvally-Steel to hit opposing Steel-types like Togedemaru and Magneton. Rock Slide is an alternative option to OHKO foes like Centiskorch and Charizard. Toxic is an alternative to Defog that lets Silvally-Steel cripple foes like Jellicent and Palossand that it can only pivot out against. Parting Shot is the preferred pivoting option to make switch-ins like Magmortar easier to switch into for another teammate; however, U-turn is helpful for the chip damage it provides and its ability to ease prediction against Regirock. 160 Speed EVs and a Jolly nature allow Silvally-Steel to outspeed Magmortar to get a Parting Shot off before it can attack. Wallbreakers like Arctovish and Sneasel can capitalize on the safe switches in Silvally-Steel can provide. Aromatisse can help check the Fighting-types that pressure Silvally-Steel and provide it with Wish support. Lanturn can provide Heal Bell support, checks Fire-types like Charizard for Silvally-Steel, and also forms a pivoting core with Volt Switch. Jellicent likewise pairs well with Silvally-Steel, answering both the Fire- and Fighting-type Pokemon that trouble it.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description: Swords Dance allows Silvally-Steel to break through most of its usual checks, notably allowing it to 2HKO Palossand and OHKO Rhydon, making it a decent wallbreaker. Flame Charge provides coverage to hit opposing Steel-types like Magneton. It also provides a Speed boost, which prevents faster foes like Choice Scarf Passimian from revenge killing Silvally-Steel, making it a potential late-game wincon. Rock Slide provides necessary coverage to OHKO Fire-types like Centiskorch and Charizard. Explosion is an alternative option that can OHKO these foes as well as bulky Water-types like Qwilfish and Lanturn at the cost of Silvally-Steel fainting; however, one must be wary of these Water-types avoiding it with Protect or an aggressive double switch. Swords Dance Silvally-Steel fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its wallbreaking and late-game sweeping potential. Scrafty and Tsareena can help pressure the bulky Water-types that give Silvally-Steel issues. Mesprit can check Fighting-types like Passimian for Silvally-Steel, and can use Healing Wish to give it a strong second chance at sweeping. Charizard and Gigalith can check foes like Whimsicott and Ribombee to make up for Silvally-Steel's lack of bulk on this set.

Togedemaru.overview: Togedemaru stands out as one of the best Choice Scarf users in the tier thanks to its solid Speed tier, great offensive and defensive typing that allows it to check Pokemon such as Archeops and Whimsicott, ability to gain momentum through U-turn, and good abilities. Its unique defensive typing and access to recovery in Wish also makes Togedemaru a useful special wall for taking on certain difficult threats such as Ribombee and Vikavolt. However, despite its excellent set of resistances, its mediocre bulk and an unreliable recovery move limits Togedemaru's ability to directly switch into threats. Sitting at base 96 Speed, it is one of the fastest Choice Scarf users and can outspeed boosted setup sweepers like Modest Ludicolo and Silvally-Fairy. However, Togedemaru fails to OHKO many of these Pokemon due to its only average Attack stat and coverage options. Togedemaru faces strong competition as a specially defensive Steel-type from the noticeably bulkier Silvally-Steel and Galarian Stunfisk and as a Wish passer from Aromatisse due to its much higher HP stat.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Toxic is useful for crippling switch-ins like Palossand and Vikavolt rather than merely pivoting out with U-turn, while Encore is more effective at annoying bulky setup sweepers such as Scrafty. Lightning Rod is useful for pivoting into Volt Switch users such as Rotom and Vikavolt, but the chip damage from Iron Barbs is preferred if there is already an Electric-immune Pokemon on the team. Iron Barbs also helps defeat opposing Choice Scarf Togedemaru. While Togedemaru can be used throughout the match to tank some resisted hits, it is best brought in as a revenge killer or through slow pivots such as Lanturn and Uxie, which form a VoltTurn core with it. Due to Togedemaru's poor damage output, it appreciates entry hazards from the likes of Gigalith and Froslass to help wear down its foes. Wallbreakers such as Whimsicott and Magmortar can also help wear down the opposing team so Togedemaru can potentially clean late-game, and they also serve as checks for threats to Togedemaru such as Palossand and Vikavolt, respectively.

sets.name: Wish Passer
sets.description: Iron Head is Togedemaru's attacking move of choice because it better threatens Pokemon Togedemaru is aiming to check such as Frosmoth and Whimsicott and does not leave Togedemaru unable to hit Ground-types. U-turn allows Togedemaru to slightly circumvent its passivity by pivoting on predicted switches, but Toxic cripples many Pokemon that Togedemaru cannot do much damage to such as Vikavolt. Heavy-Duty Boots significantly decreases Togedemaru's weakness to Spikes, Leftovers helps make it slightly less reliant on Wish, and Rocky Helmet in tandem with Iron Barbs allows Togedemaru to punish a wide variety of contact attackers. However, Lightning Rod is preferred to stop Volt Switch users such as Vikavolt and Rotom. 8 Speed EVs allow Togedemaru to outspeed Adamant Centiskorch and Modest Frosmoth. Togedemaru can support many teammates lacking recovery with Wish, such as Weezing and Uxie, both of which also help against the Fighting-and Ground-types that threaten Togedemaru. Setup sweepers that can take advantage of Fighting- and Ground-types, such as Nasty Plot Mesprit and Quiver Dance Ribombee, appreciate being brought in through Togedemaru's U-turn.

Thwackey.overview: While there are better Grass-types in the tier such as Whimsicott and Trevenant, Thwackey primarily stands out with Grassy Surge, letting it support setup sweepers like Hitmonlee and making it a decent wallbreaker and revenge killer. It has limited coverage, but it can make up for that with Grassy Glide, raw strength behind its STAB Wood Hammer, and the utility of Knock Off and U-turn. However, the tier has a fair amount of Grass-resistant Pokemon that can outspeed and threaten Thwackey such as Charizard and Whimsicott. Thwackey also competes with Tsareena, which has better bulk, superior coverage, more natural strength, and access to Rapid Spin.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description: Choice Band allows Thwackey to maximize its power combined with Grassy Terrain. Knock Off is able to cripple common Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Charizard and Tangela. U-turn allows Thwackey to pivot on Grass-resistant that are not heavily bothered by Knock Off such as Weezing and Silvally-Steel. Grassy Surge allows Thwackey to support setup sweepers such as Grassy Seed Hitmonlee and Swoobat. Ribombee is able to form a U-turn core with Thwackey and switch it in against bulky Water-types like Lanturn. Ribombee also appreciates Thwackey weakening Steel-types. Together, they can overwhelm Grass-resistant Pokemon like Weezing and Togedemaru.
